B000EULJLU|5.0|I wasn't expecting much from Tool, I mean five years later and they still have their touch? Sure enough I was blown away and impressed that Tool continues to enlighten the current music culture. People that are bashing this album were expecting another AEnima. The album just flew way over their heads. I also think that this is better than Lateralus. All of the musical tracks suck you in like an undertow and won't let go until it's finally over. 10,000 Days is the album for any Tool fan. If you're expecting another AEnima, you might want to take second thoughts. The CD packaging is really neat too, you'll have to see it for yourself.    1. Vicarious 10/10 - The first single off the album and it works. It begins with a repetive guitar riff that lasts about 40 seconds. Once the riff is over you can tell the song is going to go somewhere. When the song kicks in there is no escape. It's a really good song with a catchy lyrics. Danny really rips the drums in this song, especially towards the songs end. There is also a Schism-esque to it.    2. Jambi 9/10 - Another instant classic. Starts off with copter-like short chops at the guitar. It begins with a calmer side, but after a few chorus' it erupts and falls into a catchy beat. At this point Maynard starts to use the voice box, which is a cool addition to the song. It goes on for a little too long, but in the long run it's a great addition to the song. An classic off the album, bound to be liked.    3. Wings For Marie (Part 1) 9/10 - Wow. This song might be one of my favorites on the album. It begins with almost silence with these little bounces. When the main riff begins it's hard to let go. It's very calm and nothing like the last two tracks. It's a song to relax to and enjoy. The song has sadness to it, because it speculates about Maynard's mother Judith Maire Keenan who was paralyzed. When the song slowly spirals to an end it leads into...    4. 10,000 Days (Wings Part 2) 9/10 - Part two of an amazing two parter. Thisone has a lot more energy to it. It is a buildup song which finally releases it's energy. It's an 11 minute song so give it some time to sink in. It has the same riff but it seems to be a song more adrenaline to it. It's a great way to end the duet. After the main chorus it's pretty instrumental from there with some amazing guitar work from Jones.    5. The Pot 8/10 - \\"Who are you to wave your finger?\\" begins this track. It's a total mood change from WFM and TTD. It starts off with just vocals and when the guitar kicks in it explodes into a pure rock song. I think it's a cross between Vicarious and Jambi. There's not much more to it.    6. Lipan Conjuring 3/10 - I realize it's a filler, but it throws the flow of the album off track. It's pretty much Mantra with spoons and little tings with tribal chanting in the background. Skip it, nothing special.    7. Lost Keys (Blame Hoffman) 5/10 - A conversation between a nurse and a LSD patient. It's kind of a filler, but it's cool to listen to because it gives Rosetta Stoned a purpose.    8. Rosetta Stoned - 8/10 Reminds me of Ticks & Leeches. Picks off right where Lost Keys ends. It's an 11 minute rock song with some quick singing. The way Maynard sings the song makes him seem like he's sick, or in this case a patient. Has some moments like Jambi. This is a song to blast on your headphones. The voice box is used in this song.    9. Intension 6/10 - I just don't like it. Sounds like APC too much. It's almost a techno version of Wings For Marie. Very calm and nothing sticks out. It's a hit or miss song.    10. Right In Two 10/10 - The ballad. It's an amazing song that starts off peacefully and explodes at the end. A song with some great guitar work and drum work. It's a song that you can't turn away from.    11. Viginti Tres 6/10 - \\"Thirty-three\\" is a weird way to end the album. It's weird static and wind noises. It's almost like it had auido recording of a hurricane. It's a cross between Faaip De Oaid and (-) Ions. It doesthe trade off where it switches speaker sides with weird noises. It's a cool track to listen to and it wasn't a bad way to end it off. Towards the middle though it gets a little hectic and picks up. You'll have to hear it for yourself.    10,000 Days is an album for any Tool fan. Buy it, it's worth every penny.

B000ETQRCM|4.0|The self angst and anger that permeated Pearl Jam's earlier work is here, directed toward the war (actually, war in general) and a president whom they despise. But those who are looking for  empty-headed sloganeering and sneering  discontent will be disappointed. Pearl Jam forges it's forceful, hard edged rock with lyrics that make you couple images and ideas together.  They make their point without being condenscending or insulting (I'm sure Eddie Vedder will save that sort of thing for his on-stage rantings that we've all grown to know and love), unlike sections of their previous studio release \\"Riot Act\\".  It's not perfect by any means (\\"Parachutes\\" is a bit flimsy, while \\"Big Wave\\" is strictly nonessential), but when you have powerhouse numbers like \\"Life Wasted\\", \\"World Wide Suicide\\", \\"Unemployable\\" and what may be the best thing they've recorded in years, \\"Inside Job\\", you can't go wrong.

B000063COX|5.0|To some Iron Maiden are a joke, well because to them heavy metal itself is a joke (whereas other bands like for example Coldplay, U2 are the modern day Beatles) and there's not much point in trying to convince them how incredible something like Seventh Son of a Seventh Son is.    But this album is a whole different thing, before Maiden evolved into a more \\"traditional\\" metal sound. This is before the time of Bruce Dickinson and Number of the beast, when Paul Di'anno with his shorter hair, more raw, slightly punk style vocals was the leader. There is simply no way you can dislike this album, no one sang with that much feeling and sincerity, no one more determined than Steve Harris (who wrote nearly all the songs here) to lead his band to true greatness. This comes from a time when Iron Maiden had SOUL, not something that metal music in general is associated with. The Maiden signature sound is present from day one, but the song writing and playing is of a higher standard, whether it's Harris bass lines, Clive Burr's (one of rock's most criminally overlooked drummers) grooves or Dave Murray's Hendrix influenced, unstructured soloing. When Paul Di'anno sang no one listening to it is left in any doubt that he felt how he sang. If you can't feel the being of Remember Tommorow and Strangeworld you have no soul. Dennis Stratton's opening solo on the latter track (atleast I think that's him) is out of this world and should rank as one of the best guitar solo's written for it's emotion if not complexity. Sad he was fired after the first Maiden album because his evolving music style was at odds with the bands.     Then there's the rockers Prowler, Running Free, Charlotte, Sanctuary. Any album with a string of songs like these could only be called classic. A band nowadays could build their career with just one of these songs. And ofcourse there's the first of their long epics, Phantom of the opera which despite it's subject is not a cheese fest like Webber's awful music. This is one of Maiden's definitive moments one that would influence scores of musicians worldwide in the decades since.    This is an incredibly powerful album, there has been no rock/metal album that has mattered as much as this since that time (all due respect to people like Nirvana, Radiohead, Metallica, but sorry you never stood a chance against Maiden circa 1979-88. Maiden's debut stands at the pinnacle of greatness, it's as essential listening as Led Zeppelin I & II.
B000024D4R|5.0|Roger Waters wrote all of Pink Floyd's Lyrics after Obscured By Clouds.  This album is no exception. <br /> <br />The CD opens with the short, sweet, Pigs on the Wing (Pt. 1).  The song was a love song written by Waters for his then-wife.  It is a about people with no empathy, who are Pigs on the Wing.  In flying terms, a Pig on the Wing is an enemy fighter in your blind spot. 5/5 <br /> <br />PotW(1) is followed by Dogs, the longest song on the album.  About greedy, corrupt, money-grubbing backstabbers, it is among Waters' best lyrical achievements.  Add that to excellent music, excellent vocals, and the ingenious idea of playing dogs barking on Wright's keyboard, and you have a masterpiece. <br /> <br />Then comes Pigs (3 Different Ones).  This song is about one kind of pig, and two specific ones.  The first stanza is about the greed of capitalists (with your head down in the pig bin, sayin' keep on diggin', pig stain on your fat chin, what do you hope to find, down in the pig mine).  The second pig (second stanza) is about Margaret Thatcher, who Waters absolutely despised, as evidenced in the Final Cut.  The third stanza is about Mary Whitehouse.  I do not know who she is, but I would guess she was a censor (you're trying to keep our feelings off the street. <br /> <br />Following this is Sheep, about an uprising of the poeple.  This song is over ten minutes, like the previous two, but not nearly as good.  The album closes with PotW(2), which finishes the album much as it began, in excellence.
1592401791|1.0|This is the biggest literary disappointment I have ever experienced.    If you are assuming that the studio engineer who spent the best part of 4 to 5 years (on and off) as the Beatles sound engineer has written a book with the minutia of the studio and the recording process, the guitars used, the mics, the keyboards, the sessions that went well and those that didn't, mistakes that worked, real studio stories (rather than the same ones that Macca brings out every time he's interviewed by Michael Parkinson) ... all the great stuff that is just touched on in the Lewishon books ....., then you'll be sadly mistaken.    Yeah there are snippets of information that are interesting, but if you are into the Beatles in such a way that the above described information is what you're looking for, then don't waste your money as I did with this book.  Stick with the books by Lewishon and the Doug Suply book on the GET BACK sessions.    I have read more informative books on the Beatles by people who weren't even there.    Also the personal attacks he makes on other members of the Abbey road staff (viz: Chris Thomas) are just not called for.  It is one thing to describe an argument that occurred, but to be vitriolic and personal is not on. B000002UAU|5.0|If you are like me and you love to put the Beatles into periods or \\"sound categories\\". If so, then the Summer of 67's release of Sgt Pepper is at the peak of their Psychedelic sound period.  <br /> <br />Pre-1965, the Boys were hinting at a more experimental drug induced sound, but it wasn't as purposeful as on the 1965 relwase of Rubber Soul. With tracks like \\"Norwegian Wood\\" and \\"The Word\\", the Beatles were discovering new dimensions, litterally. However, 1966's Revolver LP is by far considered to be the album that proved what some had already known...The Beatles were taking LSD. They changed, their music had changed, and they wanted to change the listener. <br /> <br />It is only natural then that Sgt Pepper would come along. Well, all was not well in Beatledom. In 1966 John made an offhand comment about the Beatles being bigger than Jesus. Touring had already proved redundant and phsycially exhausting. Relationships were strained and drugs were consumed. In fact, John had felt he would've given up being a Beatle if not for the others mainly Paul. John had always been the strong was, but he could no longer be bothered to lead the group. <br /> <br />Here's were the impossible happens! Now, I am a John guy, but the following passage is written because it is the truth. Paul seized the moment of John's faltering ego and developed the concept for the Pepper art and musical direction, not to mention assisting with mixing. Pepper was an earth shattering experience! Paul was responsible and he made it known. The Beatles would never be the same. Oh, they did hit many other peaks musically, but Pepper was like coming to the crossroads. <br /> <br />Side note: <br /> <br />The Beatles, up to 1966, main composers were, John Lennon with 40 songs, 29 for McCartney and 14 Lennon/McCartney.  <br /> <br />You can see John had a firm grip on the group as leader and creative director.  <br /> <br />After Revolver, an LP which Paul had more songs than John (by 1), Paul had 41 songs! John 33 and 3 Lennon/McCartney (I know they are all Lennon/McCartney). <br /> <br />It was all downhill from here. The Beatles kept falling apart. Still great records like The White Album and Abbey Road. But the story is not worth mentioning unless you want me to get upset. And possibly upset others. <br /> <br />Now go buy Sgt Pepper (Revolver is better).

It draws an intricately interlinked narrative arc from the newly discovered South Pacific of the 1850s to Europe back to the Pacific over several centuries stretching into our future, through technological dystopias - and more positive - some  technological -  views of our human future. <br />Of course there is loads of (fictional) music in it. 0060922583|4.0|Talbot is obviously a very mystic person. He believes in almost every aspect of the psychic realm from hauntings to miraculous spontaneous healings to psychokinesis and \\"mental time travel\\". In this book, he covers every iota of psychic powers in a very detailed and methodical way, and relates those paranormal activities to his theory that the world is a hologram. After reading his argument, the theory definitely fits the problem and cannot be easily explained away. Of course, like all theories that seem definitive and true in the present, the future dictates which theories survive. Is it possible the universe is a hologram? Yes, but is it probable? Maybe. The most interesting chapter speaks of the incredible amount of evidence supporting spontaneous healing and the placebo effect. Essentially that there exists tons of evidence of healing through faith and the mind, belief that one can and will be healed...even diseases such as cancer. It may be a far stretch to relate healing to a holographic reality but Talbot does a fine job covering the bases. Very interesting and thought-provoking. Especially for those who are thirsty for knowledge and humbly admit that everyone has knowledge to share.
B000002U82|5.0|Imagine yourself in an insane asylum.  You might hear some of this: <br /> <br />\\"I've been mad for f****** years.  Absolutely.\\" <br />\\"I've always been mad, I know I've been mad.  You have to explain why you're mad, even if you're not mad.\\" <br />\\"Here for today, gone tommorrow.  That's me.  Hahahahahahaha\\" <br />\\"I don't know, I was really drunk at the time.\\" <br />\\"Give him a short, sharp shock and he won't do it again.  Dig it?\\" <br />\\"Why should I be afraid to die?  There's no reason for it.  You've got to go sometime.\\" <br />\\"There is no dark side of the moon, really.  Matter of fact, it's all dark\\" <br /> <br />Or you might just be listening to the most groundbreaking album of all time, in the comfort of your own room.  And I haven't even gotten to the highlights yet, to the music that made it happen. <br /> <br />The album opens with Speak To Me/Breathe.  Speak To Me introduces the album with the heartbeat from Eclipse, the clocks from Time, the engine from On the Run, the money sounds from Money, and the screaming from The Great Gig in the Sky.  After the screaming subsides, the music starts, as we transition into Breathe, about being born, and advice on how you live your life. <br /> <br />Next up is On The Run, a frenetic instrumental about paranoia.  It could be paranoia like that which overtook Stalin, who felt the world was out to get him, or it could just be the simple paranoia a person feels running to get to a flight. <br /> <br />Time follows, and is about people who think life lasts forever, and before they know it, end up to old to live, without having ever done anything meaningful.  It ends with a reprise of Breathe, about a funeral. <br /> <br />This leads into The Great Gig in the Sky, the second instrumental on the album.  This particular one is about death, as can be seen in the \\"why should I be afraid to die\\" quote above.  Clare Torry's shrieks of desperation are unrivalable, when anyone else even attempts it, it sounds like sex, the exactopposite of death. <br /> <br />Money follows, with the absolutely amazing technical achievement of the looping cash register/coins clinking/paper tearing sequence, all leading to an almost reggae (although much better) song about the evils of money, with the almost paradoxical line (money, it's a crime, share it fairly but don't take a slice of my pie). <br /> <br />There is a brief interim period in the last fifteen seconds of this song and the first five of the next in which one of the most amazing song lyrics ever appears twice (once in each song).  \\"I don't know, I was really drunk at the time.\\" <br /> <br />This leads into Us and Them, the most moody song on the album.  It's about the evils of war, and the little things we never think about, like how the soldiers on the other side are only human, too. <br /> <br />Next up is Any Colour You Like, an instrumental.  However, like every song on the album, this too has a meaning.  It is about racism, and how it doesn't really matter what color you are, you can still be a productive member of society (and you can still go insane). <br /> <br />Brain Damage follows, the culmination of all of the previous songs.  It's about how the person finally cracks, and is sent to the insane asylum (or the dark side of the moon) where he can be with all the other people like him. <br /> <br />Eclipse rounds off the album, summing up all the factors that make you go insane, ending with: \\"and all that is now, and all that is gone, and all that's to come, and everything under the sun is in tune, but the sun is eclipsed by the moon\\" (eclipse were thought to cause seizures). <br /> <br />Put this all together, and you have the best concept album ever conceived, about all the factors that lead a man to insanity: <br />paranoia, thinking about time and growing old, worrying about death, wondering if you have enough money, the stress of war, and racism. <br /> <br />Now imagine yourself in a theatre.  Not a movie theatre, but an honest-to-god theatre, where real people do real live acting for your benefit.  You're there to see a play.  On the stage is a chair, with a table next to it.  On the table is a cd player, in the chair is a man, hanging his head, so you can't see his face.  The play you're going to see is called \\"The Soundtrack to Life.\\" <br /> <br />In the play, the man lifts up his head, picks up his arm, and presses one button on the cd player.  After five seconds of silence, in which the man returns to his original position, you begin to hear a heartbeat, followed by some clocks, and an engine, the sounds of money, and some shrieks.  And then the first note of Breathe comes on. <br /> <br />Who is the man?  You are the man.  After you hang your head, close your eyes for the next 42 minutes or so. <br /> <br />You'll get your money's worth. <br /> <br />So sit back, relax, and enjoy the show.  And please, no smoking. Pink Floyd is not drug music.  This CD will take you anywhere you want to go on its own.

B000002UA0|5.0|A lot of Pink Floyd fans don't know about Syd Barrett, the genious behind this album.  While this album is certainly not as good as what would come under the direction of Roger Waters, this is still amazing, especially for a debut album. <br /> <br />This album was recorded at the same time as the Beatles' Sgt. Pepper's, and this one is much better. <br /> <br />The album opens with Astronomy Domine, a song with the closest to gibberish for lyrics Syd Barrett ever came (contrary to popular opinion, Syd did actually write coherent lyrics), and it absolutely amazing.  From the opening beeping to the excellent line, \\"stairway scare dan dare who's there\\" to the closing that brings everything to an end, this song is pure genious. 5/5 <br /> <br />Following this is Lucifer Sam, a song dedicated to Syd Barrett's girlfriend of the time.  If only all modern love songs were more like this. 5/5 <br /> <br />Next comes Matilda Mother, one of Syd Barrett's best works, and perhaps my favorite on the album. 5/5 <br /> <br />Flaming is next, and it is an extremely freaky song, but once you get past that, it's the fourth consecutive example of genius on this album. 4.5/5 <br /> <br />The next two tracks are my least favorite on the album.  Pow R. Toc H. is the least moving of all of Syd Barrett's songs, and only earns 2.5/5.  Next is Take Up Thy Stethoscope and Walk, one of Roger Waters'worst lyrical efforts, but has an excellent instrumental ending, which redeems the song enough to earn 3.5/5. <br /> <br />The next song returns to form.  Interstellar Overdrive is considered to be the psychadelic experience, and it is amazing. This song was written by all of the band members.4.5/5 <br /> <br />Then comes The Gnome, another good song, but weak in comparison to the rest.  A little bit childish. 4/5 <br /> <br />Following this is Chapter 24, an underrated song that is inspired by the Tao/Dao. 4/5 <br /> <br />Next up is the Scarecrow, a folksy tune that I greatly enjoy, although it could be better, I suppose. 4/5 <br /> <br />The last song is Bike, and it is my favorite.  It is another love song, about a boy who will do anything to get a girl's attention.  Absolutely Barrett (which, if you read the title, is synonamous with about a 9.5 on a scale of one to ten). <br /> <br />Thank you for your time, and I'm sure Amazon thanks you for your money and Pink Floyd for your support.

After a DISASTEROUS first season, and a not much better second season, who would have thought that Next Generation's third season would be a tour-de-force of great acting and storytelling? And yet, that's exactly what happened. Coming off the writers' strike of season 2, Season 3 roared out of the gate with the return of Gates McFadden as Dr. Crusher. Season 2 had seen Crusher replace by the hated Dr. Pulaski, whose Enterprise tenure was thankfully only one season. In addition, Whoopie Goldberg as Guinan was featured prominently as a supporting character in this season, which added immeasurably to the ensemble cast dynamic. The introduction of Worf's continuing Klingon saga in this season was the start of Next Generation's continuing storylines, and the dark nature of the Klingon story arc was fantastic. In addition, the scriptwriters and the actors finally 'found' the characters after two wildly uneven seasons, and the classic portrayal of the Next Generation characters would begin right here in season 3. The true shining moments of season 3, however, are the cliffhanger season finale (which truly introduces the Borg after a cameo appearance in season 2), and one of the greatest Star Trek episodes of all time: Yesterday's Enterprise (featuring the return of Denise Crosby as Tasha Yar). Add in the expanded characterization of all the main cast, the SUPERB storylines, and the fact that there is not a single bad (or even average!) episode in this season, and you get the finest single year Star Trek has ever seen. Season 3 single handedly turned Next Generation into a television legend. If you like sci-fi, Next Generation's season 3 is an absolute MUST OWN. Following up season 3 was the equally impressive season 4, which is also mandatory viewing. HIGHEST POSSIBLE RECOMMENDATION!
006056251X|5.0|'Devil in Winter' by Lisa Kleypas is excellent novel. I finished it in one evening and loved every moment! Four young ladies enter London society with one common goal: they must use their feminine wit and wiles to find a husband. Therefore, a daring husband-hunting scheme is born. This is the story of Evangeline who is shy stuttering wallflower. Her father owns a gamble establishment but is denied to visit him by her cruel extended family. She decided to escapes from the abuse and marries Sebastian who needs her inheritance - but is an infamous rake. The Wallflower Quartet Series; Secrets of a Summer Night, It Happened One Autumn, The Devil In Winter and Scandal in Spring (coming out August 2006). I love this series buy them all and enjoy!

B000EULJLU|4.0|You probably shouldn't believe the hyperbole on either side.  The truth is that Lateralus was a far more cohesive album, both musically and lyrically.  My first impression (based on about 3 full listen throughs) is that this album isn't really a step forward for the band, so much as it is a maintenance of the status quo.  Don't get me wrong, when the disc is awesome... it's AWESOME (Vicarious, Jambi, The Pot are initial standouts in my mind).  Please keep that in mind when you read the following. <br /> <br />Lyrically I haven't found this album to be nearly as impressive as previous releases.  If Lateralus was all extended metaphor and innuendo, 10,000 Days is a sledghammer upside the head (see Right in Two and Vicarious).  A lot of the contemplative mood and humor survive from Lateralus, but we also add in a healthy dose of the anger of Undertow and Aenima which had all been focused into Ticks and Leeches on Lateralus. <br /> <br />The best songs in terms of lyrics on the album are Wings for Marie and 10,000 Days.  However, this brings up another problem for me.  I saw TOOL on the Lateralus tour and they did an intermission where Adam Jones stood and played a little three note riff from one of the songs over and over for about 5-10 minutes while the rest of the band took a breather.  That's fine for the live show.  But too much of 10,000 Days (the song) sounds like that extended intermission riff, it just repeats for a really long time.  That's a problem, because I never felt like anything in Lateralus or in the substantive portions of Aenima was like that. <br /> <br />In any event, I'd like to close by reassuring fans (as if you haven't bought this album already) that the CD is really, really good.  It's also worth noting that TOOL songs usually grow on me with time as I discover all of the nuanced stuff that's going on (that's my hope for 10,000 Days) that's not readily apparent on the first few listens.  Finally, a recommendation:  If this is the first TOOL purchase you are considering, buy Lateralus and then branch out.  You'll appreciate this much more by starting elsewhere.
0596009208|4.0|This book will not be for everyone. The layout and teaching style may turn you off and that is ok. Everyone learns differently.    The book does cover a lot of ground, perhaps too much but more or less does so in enough depth to make this book attractive to novices and intermediate programmers.     I have two main complaints:    1. The GUI section is extremely weak. The jukebox is not as much of an example of writing a solid, good looking GUI as it is a 'whee look what I can do' example. Granted using Swing is a topic for at least an entire book(and I hope a good HF GUI book is in the works), but the lack of useful examples of common components and the terrible layout managers makes this a section of the book easily skipped.    2. Some of the client/server examples in the networking chapter block permantantly. It compiles fine, but it blocks forever. There is not a deep enough discussion on IO and networking to make this a useful chapter.    Other then those two quibbles, which might be very minor depending on your point of view, this is a fun, generally well-written book that anyone should be able to use to great effect.

B00025ETIW|5.0|Three Cheers for Sweet Revenge, the sophomore album from My Chemical Romance, is one of the two best CDs I own. The other is I Brought You My Bullets, You Brought Me Your Love, their debut album. Revenge is a haunting and imaginative blend of melodies and appropriate tempos for each amazing song. Whether you are listening to the album all the way through, or rockin' out to your favorites, every single song on this album delivers incredibly beautiful vocals, haunting and metaphor-laden lyrics, energetic instrumentals, and a stirring message of hope. It is both sorrowful and revitalizing, haunting and melodic, and great to sing along to. I cannot say enough good things about this album.  <br /> <br />Helena- Probably the most well-known song by My Chemical Romance and one of the best songs I have ever heard. The change of tempo from the verses to the refrain makes this song one of the most powerful and beautiful on the album. The vocals are absolutely incredible, and the video is absolutely amazing. <br /> <br />Give 'Em Hell, Kid- Very fun song with great bass and a wonderful melody. Awesome to sing along to, and has one of the happiest beats on the album. (I will also add that it is currently #1 on my Top 25 Most Played on my iTunes, right above I'm Not Okay (I Promise) and Our Lady of Sorrows, although I love them all equally.) <br /> <br />To The End- Incredible guitar and striking lyrics. \\"Say goodbye to the hearts you break and all the cyanide you drank.\\" This song is based on a piece of literature, as is much of the band's material (including their band name). This is one of the most visual songs on the album and contains a ton of imagery. <br /> <br />You Know What They Do To Guys Like Us In Prison- Beautiful singing, and lyrics are humorous at times. (\\"I miss my mom!\\") Strong anti-homophobia message. Additional vocals by Bert McCracken of The Used only add to this song's magnificence.  <br /> <br />I'm Not Okay (I Promise)- The greatest teen anthem of all time. Many of the lyrics are drawn from Gerard Way's real-life experiences, and the message is easy to relate to. One of the greatest songs of all time and also has a very funny video. <br /> <br />The Ghost of You- The slowest song on the album, with a strong message about loss. This song gives me chills every time I hear it, and it is incredibly sorrowful and powerful. The video is also very appropriate and it only adds to the beauty of this song. <br /> <br />The Jetset Life Is Gonna Kill You- Chilling and beautiful song, and unique due to its fade-in drums and organ intro. It was chosen as my MCR song of the week for this week. \\"Slip into the tragedy, you've spun this chamber dry.\\" <br /> <br />Interlude- Although it is just under a minute long, this song deserves as much recognition as the rest of the songs on this album. It provides a beautiful transition from the first half of the album to the second half, from the more singalong half to the darker half. It also is the perfect song to introduce \\"Thank You For The Venom,\\" and I think of these two songs as a pair. <br /> <br />Thank You For The Venom- Has the best intro of the whole album. With the soft \\"Interlude\\" placed before it chronologically, it makes the intro even more pounding and spectacular. Amazing guitar and chilling lyrics. This is one of the most energetic songs on the album, and it is great for headbanging, singing along, dancing, moshing, and anything else you can think of! Favorite lyric: \\"Hallelujah, lock and load.\\" <br /> <br />Hang 'Em High- With a unique and spectacular intro that is reminiscent of the Old West, this song is anything but saloon material. It is energetic, fast-paced, melodic, and has incredible lyrics. Favorite lyric: \\"Mass convulsions, strike the choir, by the grace of God.\\" <br /> <br />It's Not A Fashion Statement, It's A F*cking Deathwish- Amazing song, with constant changes of tempo (especially near the end) that easily make this song great to play over and over again. It's hard, it's creepy, and it's an absolutely incredible song. \\"When in the end we'll fall apart, just like the leaves changing color... When you go, just know that I will remember you. I've lost my fear of falling, I will be with you, I will be with you!\\" <br /> <br />Cemetery Drive- One of my favorite songs of all time and one of the best songs on the album. The lyrics are the most haunting and moving out of any song I have ever heard. \\"Mark the grave, where the searchlight find us drinking by the mausoleum door, and they found you on the bathroom floor. I miss you, I miss you so far.\\" This song is stirring, and this one also gives me the chills. The way Gerard sings the words is unlike anything I have ever heard in my life. <br /> <br />I Never Told You What I Do For A Living- Awesome song, and awesome lyrics. (\\"Clean me off, I'm so dirty, babe! The kind of dirty where the water never cleans off the clothes...\\") It is the perfect ending to the perfect album. It closes everything very nicely and in the signature My Chemical Romance way, creepy and cool. <br /> <br />Revenge leaves you wanting more, and is easy to listen to over and over again. The range of emotions it elicits is absolutely incredible and is so easy to relate to. It has depressing lows, soaring and invincible highs, and leaves you feeling hopeful and satisfied. I cannot recommend this album highly enough.

This album is so unbelievably good....and the mixture of intelligence and creativity just radiates from every song. After this album I can say one thing......I am very proud of TooL!!!! They have continually been one of the most original, thought provoking, creativly honest bands ever. And after this album....which comes after a 5 year break....along with the fact that the bandmembers are getting older.....they have not only NOT lost a step...they have appeared to GAIN a step, by sounding more creative and polished than ever. TooL......You guys rock!!!!!

B0007XT87G|4.0|Alice In Chains - Dirt. Live - Throwing Copper. Pearl Jam - Ten. Tool - AEnima. What do all of these have in common? A few things. Naturally, all of them were written and created by bands peerless in their timelessness and talent, but the one amazingly cool and unfortunately sad link between all of them is that they are albums which were so great in their creation, the rest of the bands career would be held in the eyes of many to be nothing more than a comparison than their great master work, every other album which will probably never measure up to it in all its glory. Thankfully Porcupine Tree have, and hopefully always will, crank out the high quality music that they are known for, indescribably tasteful pop songs set against atmospheric psychedelia and dark, brooding edginess. But chances are they will never do it quite like they did on 2002's In Absentia, the prequel to Deadwing. And thats okay. I'll be satisfied listening to In Absentia on a more than likely daily basis for the rest of my life and probably never get bored of it. But Deadwing is a damn fine attempt at a follow-up. <br /> <br />While it doesn't have the atmosphere and vibe that made In Absentia the thought-rock masterpiece it was, Deadwing hits the mark perfectly in being a great rock album, full of memorable lyrics, unforgettable, soaring choruses, original song structures, and unparralleled musicianship. But anyone who has ever heard this band knows that every album of theirs has all those qualities and more. Deadwing is more of an expansion on the heavier qualities of PT's music, probably derived from bandleader Steven Wilson's musical relationships with Opeth (the vocalist of whom performs on tracks 1, 3, and 5) and Meshuggah, and 8 of the 10 tracks on Deadwing will succeed in rocking your balls off. <br /> <br />Opening with a hypnotic synth line which holds us in suspense for the massive sound explosion that is coming, the albums title track blasts out of the speakers in the form of a 9 minute exercise in all of PT's qualities mentioned above, reaching a musical orgasm in the form of a blistering guitar solo from experimental guest guitarist Adrian Belew. This and the highly popular and progressive 10 minute plus Arriving Somewhere (But Not Here) are the talk of the album, both starting off as intense, passionate, but touching rockers with ballad-like vocals and melodic solos before blasting the listener with an array of pummelling metal exercises in rhythm. The latter of the two tracks is destined to become classic PT, and its lyrics question what exactly is waiting for us after death, taking the lyrics to a higher level of personality. These themes, along with the croons of a broken heart fresh out of the losing end of a relationship form the themes of the album, a ghost story written by SW and filmmaker Mike Bennion. Religion is not spared the lyrical axe either on the scathing and ominous Halo. <br /> <br />The heaviness prevails throughout most of the album, Shallow and Open Car featuring two of the most anthematic choruses from the band yet, while the remixed version of Shesmovedon (hidden track) is an amalgamut of signature PT traits, a moving chorus, outstanding guitar playing, and a ripping guitar solo to close it out. The Start Of Something Beautiful is also a big step forward for PT in the way of blending trippy guitar imagery into what would be a typical, if quality, rock song. The two quieter numbers are the minority of the album, contrary to In Absentia, much of which was acoustic and melody based in contrast to the metal influence, the piano ballad of Lazarus hitting that soft spot in the bottom of my heart every time I hear it. <br /> <br />If you've never heard this band but are just starting to hear about them as their popularity grows, this and In Absentia are the best place to start, although I reccommend the latter more than anything else. All in all Deadwing is an admirable rock album which any band should be proud to even remotely come close to making anytime in their careers. Get it now before everyone hears about it.
B000EULJLU|5.0|Maynard has never sounded better than on \\"The Pot\\", streching his vocal reach to a new high.  Trust me, you have to hear it to believe it.  Maynard also exposes his personal life in \\"Wings for Marie\\" and \\"10,000 Days\\", which is about his mothers life and the struggle she went through in the 27 years of being paralyzed (27 years is about 10,000 Days, get it?).  \\"Right In Two\\" is by far the best track on the album, if you can't make it out, make sure to read the lyrics!  Make no doubt about it, the signature tool sound is there with unbelievable change-ups throughout the entire album. B000EULJLU|5.0|5 years after the release of Lateralus and 3 and a half since they last performed a live show, Tool finally has a new album out. And it's about damn time. As usual, the wait is more than worth it, and while, like many of my favorite albums, I didn't quite get it upon the first listen, subsequent, repeated listenings have revealed not only a more structurally complex record than anything in the bands catalog to date, but also lyrically one of vocalist Maynard Keenan's most personal offerings. So many influences have come together to form this sonically unique album that it becomes hard to pinpoint exactly what these guys were on, and/or listening to when they recorded it. 10,000 Days is still an expansion of the bands first four albums, the psychedelic edginess, hammering rhythmic full band attacks, long melodic solos that cut straight to the heart, and overall atmospheric nostalgic touch giving it that distinct Tool signature. The songs are now even more progressive than on the epic Lateralus, the structures rarely depending on repeating any one part of the song, no matter how good it is, but never lacking in hooks despite this and the truly heavy quality of the material, giving the songs an almost Opethian writing quality not present on any previous release, all of which still depended heavily on choruses to grab the listeners ear. The sometimes Middle Eastern feel of the instrumental passages stay true to drummer Danny Carey's tribal tom assaults with a flair for tabla and exotic percussion, and Adam Jones use of a talk box for his guitar solo on Jambi is exceptionally prog-rock-ish and hints at a (if very slight) Frampton influence. However many childish fans still upset at this great bands fame cry and moan, it simply doesn't change the always undeniable fact about Tool: they simply keep getting better and better, all members united more structurally and rhythmically than ever before. This is, I might add, bassist Justin Chanellor's shining moment with the band,whom he has been with since AEnima, and his truly exceptional melodic bass playing strays from the typical path followed by his instrument of choice, his sense of melody and unique skill probably being enough to supplement the need for a guitar player in any other band that didn't have Adam Jones on the axe. Jones and Carey truly seem to see eye to eye on this album, guitar stroke matching every single rhythmic blast from Carey's monstrous drum set. <br /> <br />And of course there is Maynard James Keenan, the man himself. He has always been a master lyricist, from the humorous satiric debut of Opiate through the mind-opening pschedelic enlightenment of Lateralus and throughout his second band A Perfect Circle, the influence of which is also undeniable through Keenan's political yet intensely personal lyrics. While I may be wrong in my interpretation, the album seems to follow two vastly end of the spectrum themes, one being the state of humanity and politics in the world, which has always been the target of not only hope, but also machine-gun scrutiny in coming from MJK. The album's opening track and first single, Vicarious takes a well-deserved crack at fast-food fed, TV-droned Americans and their lust for televised violence, while Right In Two openly condemns the state of the Middle East, Keenan comparing humans to \\"monkey killing monkey killing monkey over pieces of the ground.\\" <br /> <br />Of equally powerful, if drastically different, importance is the presence of Keenan's mothers ghost throughout the record, whose time in a wheelchair (the years of which add up to 10,000 days) and eventual death has had a profound effect on the singer, painfully crooning on the title song \\"10,000 days in the fire is long enough...you're going home.\\" The effect is tear-jerking, being the closest this man has ever let his fans get to his soul. This is not the first time his mother has been the subject matter for his songwriting techniques, drawing namesake in the angry Perfect Circle anthem titled Judith, upon which Keenan rebukes her for her faith in a God who has left her \\"broken down and paralyzed.\\" 10,000 Days seems to be the cure and elevated perspective needed for him on this very personal subject. <br /> <br />I am reluctant to go into a song by song analysis for two reasons, one being how cohesively well the songs flow together to make the album as a whole truly a listening experience, while secondly it was just released yesterday and I haven't had quite enough time to let the subtleties of each sink in yet. But the 20 or so listens I have already had have shown me enough to know that my favorite band has failed to let me down again. Many will insult this album, as many ignorant \\"fans\\" do in terms of any good piece of art, but as 311 says \\"F the naysayers 'cause they don't mean a thing.\\" If you have remotely enjoyed anything by this band in the past, 10,000 Days will only serve its purpose in opening your mind to their message that much more. Give it a chance.
B000EULJLU|5.0|It's not Lateralus II, it isn't ?nima II, and in time we will all realize those are good things.  When Tool have made such amazing albums in the past, it's hard for fans to stomach new material.  Give this release some time, it tackles new territory by taking a step back and moving forward at the same time.  I prefer Lateralus, but this album is amazing and a continuation of Lateralus would not have been authentic.

Usually when I buy a Tool album it would take a good week of solid listening to really get into the sound and figure out what was good about it. However this album including it's insanely beautiful album arts 3D packaging (Stereo Optic Vision) is just what the doctor ordered classic Tool with the same stances as earlier works but new twists on production, you may even hear computer produced drums on Intension. B000A6T1JU|3.0|For the best, unadulterated Warriors experience, I'd avoid the Ultimate Director's Cut.  While the commentaries, \\"Where are they now\\" section and other extras are worthy, the comic strip segues now inserted between scenes will jar too heavily with anyone who remembers this film with deserved fondness.  Worse, the pauses they inject tend to trash the movie's rhythym.   <br /> <br />I own both the original and Ultimate Director's Cut, and I'd say if you're a pathetic completist (like I am) then owning both is similarly a no-brainer.  To replace that aging VHS copy of your beloved Warriors, or to enjoy the movie in its pure leather-vested glory, then only the original cut should be considered.
B000E1ZBGS|2.0|This movie was not absolutely horrible, it was alright to watch-if one does not consider it true to the novel Pride and Prejudice.  While the cinematography was beautiful and more artistic than the BBC version (they obviously had a higher budget), the storyline was cut - to below the bare minimum. To some who don't know Pride and Prejudice, it can even be slightly confusing, because nothing is elaborated on. (The music was also too loud on the DVD, and often one would miss what they are saying and must read the captions) Pivotal moments like when Darcy comments on not wanting to dance with Elizabeth seem almost trivial in the presentation of the movie. Sometimes things seem to come out of nowhere- especially when Elizabeth finds out about Lydia, one scene she's happy, the next she walks in and sobs (it was rather funny, though it's not supposed to be).  The storyline between Jane and Bingly was nowhere near as detailed as it should have been, I didn't feel it's importance. It was like the directors considered any storyline not related to Darcy and Elizabeth to be extraneous.  Kiera Knightly does not play a terrible Elizabeth Bennett, though sometimes I found her to say things in a very similar manner to Jennifer Ehle, and other times she would act completely out of character for Elizabeth (though this is probably the screenplay's fault). After Lady Catherine comes near the end, Elizabeth seems completely unreasonable and immature, crying out that she wants to be left alone - this was not how Jane Austen wrote Elizabeth to be.  Mr. Darcy is barely shown, and I didn't really feel like he was as important a character as he was supposed to be. Moments where he's spilling out his heart, the camera is instead focused more often on Elizabeth. Macfadyen didn't really play Darcy to what I imagined him in the book, Firth in the BBC version did a much better job.  There wasn't the best chemistry between Knightly and Macfadyen  and I found myself not really caring that they would end up together in the end.  There are numerous other comments that could be made, but the biggest problem with the adaptation of Pride and Prejudice, was that they over dramatized it. Lady Catherine coming at night, Charlotte Lucas running away saying Elizabeth better not judge her, the proposal in the rain. It all turns Pride and Prejudice into a story that doesn't seem unique- it becomes so cliche. Jane Austen was subtle, and the movie didn't capture that at all.  For those who have not read Jane Austen or seen the BBC version, the movie is not horrible, but to be honest it isn't a classic either.
B000AP2ZDK|5.0|Falling short of being a posthumous release, J. Dilla's instrumental album of various beats and hooks is a fresh record unlike the Ying Yang Twins and Ne-Yo genre that hip-hop has become.<br /><br />With none of the songs lasting past two minutes, it is sometimes difficult to keep track of the thirty-one frantic tracks. Yet, it all blends into one sweet trip. An amazing trip that is incredible difficult to review with all of the over-before-you-know-it songs.<br /><br />He carefully utilizes sampling in \\"Hi\\" and \\"Bye,\\" which becomes its own genre with its progressive neo-soul sound. These faded samplings, however, could become repetitive by \\"Walkinonit,\\" but J Dilla's master of his craft provides otherwise.<br /><br />This album provides the late hip-hop artist with an amazing canvas to spill his various talents on. He slows it down with some crooning in \\"One For Ghost\\" and \\"Don't Cry.\\" With the latter as the longest track on the album, however, it feels drawn out.<br /><br />Like a piece of ginger, \\"Gobstopper\\" refreshes your pallate with its sharp urban jazz stylings before taking you into \\"Thunder,\\" fresh with sirens and screams.<br /><br />For those wanting some nostalgia, \\"Geek Down\\" is a beautiful Jimi Hendrix psychadelic expierence and \\"Anti-American Graffiti\\" fuses the revolutionary sounds of 60's British bands, such as The Beatles with a hip-hop flair. J. Dilla makes Motown his own in \\"Two Can Win\\" and \\"Stop\\", some of the album's stand-outs.<br /><br />There are, however, some irrelevant tracks that are, for the most part, in the middle of the album. \\"One Eleven\\" is a waste of it's one minute and eleven second presence. \\"The Twister\\" takes on more than it can chew. \\"Stepson of the Clapper\\" has zero musical redeemability and it becomes clear that the first half of the album is much stronger than the second. This is confirmed by \\"Time\\" and \\"Waves,\\" which lasts long past its welcome mat.<br /><br />By \\"Lightworks,\\" I am beginning to understand J. Dilla's title, \\"Donuts.\\" Each song takes us through a certain era of music with a hip-hop twist. \\"Lightworks\\" sounds like it is from the soundtrack of \\"Pleasantville... Remixed\\" and \\"Airworks\\" infuses Marvin Gaye's soulful sound with his soulful beats.<br /><br />Another part of J. Dilla's multifaceted work is his use of so many instruments. \\"Mash\\" and \\"The Diff'rence\\" have beautiful uses of the piano, while many other tracks utilize the instruments of jazz. \\"People\\" is saved by its use of the bongo drums, rather than the sirens, which are used too much throughout the album.<br /><br />The shortness of the songs is never a problem until the end of the album with \\"The New\\" and \\"Light My Fire,\\" which were so short it was difficult for me to write anything worthwhile about them.<br /><br />The album finishes strong with \\"Workinonit.\\" This track is the only track that lasts more than two minutes and is an example of the amazing \\"singles\\" work of which J. Dilla is capable.<br /><br />Many of these songs taken individually is a gem. And as revolutionary this album could potentially be to the hip-hop world, the conciseness of the songs is hard to accept in a mainstream hip-hop media that only gives three to four minute songs with either crazy vocals, killer beats or overextended sexual innuendo the time of day. R.I.P: J. Dilla. This grade is no inflated number to sympathize with a late artist. This 32 year-old's music is raw. Passionate. Subtle. A rare treat.<br /><br />Overall Album: A-<br /><br />Album from Track Persepective: B+ (87)<br /><br />Download : J Dilla - Workinonit, J Dilla - Stop, J Dilla - Geek Down, J Dilla - Hi, J Dilla - Two Can Win, J Dilla - U-Love<br /><br />Skip It : J Dilla - One Eleven, J Dilla - Waves, J Dilla - Stepson of the Clapper, J Dilla - The Twister, J Dilla - TimeDilla's title, \\"Donuts.\\" Each song takes us through a certain era of music with a hip-hop twist. \\"Lightworks\\" sounds like it is from the soundtrack of \\"Pleasantville... Remixed\\" and \\"Airworks\\" infuses Marvin Gaye's soulful sound with his soulful beats. <br /> <br />Another part of J. Dilla's multifaceted work is his use of so many instruments. \\"Mash\\" and \\"The Diff'rence\\" have beautiful uses of the piano, while many other tracks utilize the instruments of jazz. \\"People\\" is saved by its use of the bongo drums, rather than the sirens, which are used too much throughout the album. <br /> <br />The shortness of the songs is never a problem until the end of the album with \\"The New\\" and \\"Light My Fire,\\" which were so short it was difficult for me to write anything worthwhile about them. <br /> <br />The album finishes strong with \\"Workinonit.\\" This track is the only track that lasts more than two minutes and is an example of the amazing \\"singles\\" work of which J. Dilla is capable. <br /> <br />Many of these songs taken individually is a gem. And as revolutionary this album could potentially be to the hip-hop world, the conciseness of the songs is hard to accept in a mainstream hip-hop media that only gives three to four minute songs with either crazy vocals, killer beats or overextended sexual innuendo the time of day. R.I.P: J. Dilla. This grade is no inflated number to sympathize with a late artist. This 32 year-old's music is raw. Passionate. Subtle. B000BISBDY|5.0|Johnny Cash wasn't just a great country musician.  He was a legend of music.  Cash arrived on the music scene around the same time as Elvis Presley and Jerry Lee Lewis.  Rock and Roll was in its infancy and Cash entered into the scene at the right time.  Cash's had a magnificent baritone voice and could play a standard acoustic guitar with the best.  He started off singing folksy rock and roll, but by the end of his life was best known as a country artist.  However, Cash never really fit into any of those genres.  He sung and wrote songs that ran a rampant of musical genres from rock and roll, country, pop, gospel, and folk.  Cash had a style and tune all of his own.  He related best to the common people and his music reflected that.  People loved him for it.  At the same time, musicians knew that Cash was much more than a good ole boy done good.  Musicians know that Cash was a musical genius and his style influenced artists as diverse from U2 to Kris Kristofferson to Nine Inch Nails.  Johnny Cash was a legend and THE LEGEND OF JOHNNY CASH captures that.  Some of Cash's most famous tunes are included on this album, e.g. \\"Folsom Prison Blues\\", \\"Ring of Fire\\", and \\"Man in Black\\".  Also included are songs he sang with wife June Carter (\\"Jackson\\") and songs that illustrate the genius of Cash, \\"Highwayman\\", \\"The Wanderer\\", \\"Rusty Cage\\", and \\"Hurt\\".  There really aren't any terrible Johnny Cash albums, but if a person can only own one album that illustrates the breadth and depth of the musical talents of Cash, THE LEGEND OF JOHNNY CASH is the album to own.
B000ETQRCM|5.0|For those of you who love concise reviews, let's just say that this is easily their best and overall most consistent work since \\"Vs\\"...dare I say, best since \\"Ten\\"?  There, for some of you, that's all you need.  Go buy the album. <br /> <br />Lost?  Not a longtime Pearl Jam fan?  Heard \\"World Wide Suicide\\" on the radio and decided to check them out?  Well, sit down, and prepare to learn what real rock and roll is.  Mindless Clear Channel drones, your savior has arrived. <br />  <br />As for the rest of you, Pearl Jam's eighth studio album, self-titled 15 years into their career, is the culmination of all their ideas and tendencies from \\"Vitalogy\\" to \\"Riot Act\\", forming a diverse and rather urgent album that fans have been waiting for for at least eight years, if not longer.  Don't get me wrong, I love every single one of PJ's albums, but we didn't get \\"Corduroy\\" and \\"Better Man\\" without \\"Bugs\\" and \\"Foxymop\\"; we didn't get \\"In My Tree\\" and \\"Red Mosquito\\" without \\"I'm Open\\"; \\"Given to Fly\\" was a little soured by the presence of \\"Push Me, Pull Me\\"; \\"Binaural\\" was just incredibly uneven, and \\"Riot Act\\", while having some real gems, was littered with filler like \\"Help Help\\" and \\"Arc\\". <br /> <br />So now Pearl Jam, with a new label, puts out a new album, and what do we get?  NO FILLER!  Experimentation is kept to a minimum, and for the first time since 1993's \\"Vs.\\", we get an album that is consistently good from start to finish.  No seven-minute musical abortions like \\"Foxymop\\" tacked on the end of the album to drag it down.  Even the one-minute \\"Wasted Reprise\\" is poignant and has nothing in common to previous crap-shorts like \\"Pry, To\\". <br /> <br />Some people, for some reason, seem to think that just because this album, heralded by many of the band members as their best work to date, is not in the same vein as \\"Ten\\", it's not a good album.  Sure, expectations were really high for this album, but let's face it, nothing can touch \\"Ten\\", and that was 15 years ago.  Let's all learn to let go of \\"Ten\\" and embrace a new, just-about-as-good era of Pearl Jam. <br /> <br />The first five songs are an all-out musical assault that is a powerful affirmation to disheartened fans that Pearl Jam, and REAL ROCK MUSIC in general, is alive and well.  \\"Life Wasted\\" (9.5/10) is a powerful, guitar-driven opener that I can see getting a lot of popular play at concerts.  \\"World Wide Suicide\\" (9.5/10) is the one we've all heard already, and it's not even the best song on the album, though it's the best choice for a single from Pearl Jam since at least Given to Fly.  \\"Comatose\\" (9/10) is strikingly similar to \\"Spin the Black Circle\\", only five times better.  Fast and furious, and Eddie sounds straight out of Vitalogy.  \\"Severed Hand\\" (9/10) has a really cool opener, and while I'm not too keen on some of the vocals (too weak - sounds at times like \\"Riot Act\\"-era Eddie), it's a solid, rocking tune with a good ending.  \\"Marker in the Sand\\" (9.5/10) is one of the strongest tracks on the album, alternating between heavy, powerful verses and a beautiful, melodic, radio-friendly chorus that sounds like it would fit well on Yield.  \\"Parachutes\\" (9.5/10) is a soft, Beatles-esque acoustic ballad that brings the listener down slowly after the first five tracks, with some great singing by Eddie.  \\"Unemployable\\" (9.5/10) has some great drumming from Matt and a catchy chorus, though the verses are a little annoying.  \\"Big Wave\\" (9.5/10) is an exciting, fast-paced track with an awesome chorus, though I'm not too keen on the surfer theme.  \\"Gone\\" (9.5/10), a song about driving, bears a resemblance to \\"In Hiding\\" with its soft verses and euphoric chorus.  \\"Wasted Reprise\\" (8.5/10), a slower rendition of the chorus of \\"Life Wasted\\" to an organ, is the weakest track on the album, though even at a minute, it's still not skip-worthy.  \\"Army Reserve\\" (9/10) (in my opinion) has stylistic similarities to Riot Act, though it would have been one of the best songs on that album,with interesting time changes and a powerful chorus that rocks to solid drumming.  \\"Come Back\\" (9.5/10) took a long time for me to really get into, but now I love it.  A beautiful ballad, with some of the best singing from Eddie since at least Vitalogy, that is destined to become a concert staple, and if it weren't for purists, it has the potential to overtake \\"Yellow Ledbetter\\" as a concert-ender.  The album closes out with the best track, \\"Inside Job\\" (10/10), with some somewhat iffy lyrics by McCready.  Still, laced with beautiful piano and heartfelt singing from Eddie, it has a few prog rock elements that liken it to Pink Floyd, and its progression from a soft ballad to a rocker reminds me a bit of \\"Hard to Imagine\\" from Lost Dogs. <br /> <br />A strong vocal performance from Eddie that would make you think he has jumped back ten years, the perfect collaboration of all the bandmates, and some of the best songwriting in years all come together to form the masterwork of their later years.  Forget \\"Yield.\\"  Heck, forget \\"Vitalogy\\" and \\"Vs.\\".  \\"Avocado\\" is the new king of the mountain. <br /> <br />Besides, what else are we going to listen to?  My Chemical Romance?  I rest my case. <br /> <br />5 Stars. <br /> <br />(And for those of you who don't know, the avocado is the symbol of the Green Party, to which Eddie belongs.) <br />

0060736267|5.0|A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, written by Betty Smith, is a fabulous novel, which is about a young girl growing up poor in Williamsburg, Brooklyn with her family and neighbors.  This novel was published in 1943 by Harper and Brothers Publishing and was selected as one of the Books of the Century by the New York Public Library.  Francie Nolan, the protagonist of this story, is a delightful young child with such great determination to succeed and to get an education.  This novel is so interesting, because it shows how the hardship of daily life was like back in the 1900s.  Francie Nolan has a very tough time growing up in Brooklyn at age 11.  Part of this reason is because her father is an alcoholic, who struggles tremendously, therefore not being able to be a good father.  This comes down to Francie having an empty stomach continuously.  Francie is such a gentle and obedient young girl who is a mix of both the Nolan family and the Rommely family, though she is more of her own person.  She acquires her own personality and own traits through her observations and readings, which really makes Francie a live and brilliant character. <br />    A Tree Grows in Brooklyn was written very methodically, with the chapters going through Francie's life year by year, consisting with times when you can just about break out into tears, and times when you are just angry with a specific character.  The conflicts, in which take place in Francie Nolan's life, are so realistic and entertaining that any reader will fall in love with the protagonist, Francie Nolan.   <br />    Betty definitely achieved her purpose in writing this novel, for she intended for readers both young and mature to realize how fortunate they are to have up to three meals a day, while Francie considered it a blessing to eat only a slice of stale bread.    A Tree Grows in Brooklyn strongly emphasizes the value of reading and education very clearly, but more significant, the importance of family and friends who will doanything to keep you safe from the real world.       <br />

B000E6UWE4|1.0|I was recommended this book by someone whose opinion I trust, and a new fantasy author always piques my interest. However, over 200 pages in, and I can safely say that my interest is now de-piqued.<br /><br />While Erikson has some considerable ability with world-building - and his city heated / illuminated by gas is wonderfully visual - I should have known better when I saw his 3-4 page list of Dramatis Personae. I should have known better when the plot showed no apparent central thrust after page 100, and instead of a solid spine to hook onto, I was left with myriad mini-plots revolving around conspiracy, magic, political convolutions, murder, more magic, prophecy, more magic . . .<br /><br />It became increasingly difficult to get past the calculations necessary to figure out who was allied with who in order to gain any sympathy for the characters. I sorta can see Tattersail as central, but the pov switches too often for me to get behind her as a main protag. Then there's Paran, who gets murdered and conveniently brought back to life, and Whiskeyjack and his Bridgeburners, who show real promise, but they aren't on stage often enough for me to ally myself with them. In fact, NO-ONE remains onstage for very long. I was just getting used to Sail and co when Kruppe and his merry men show up, and I seriously considered ditching the book right then and there.<br /><br />Neither does the plot show anything resembling a central story. I've no idea what any of the main characters want, except Laseen, who just wants power. Why should I be interested in a story which apparently has no stakes? Characters appear and die, and so what?<br /><br />Sorry, Mr Erikson. I had high hopes for this novel. I won't buy the second.

What incites me to write a review is how ridiculous Dan Brown has been on television hyping up his book by saying he was a \\"skeptic\\" until \\"extensively researching\\" where he has now become a believer in his work.<br /><br />Brown provides a preliminary page of \\"facts\\" that are used to back up his fiction. That the \\"facts\\" are wrong and widely denounced as poorly researched reflects poorly on Brown as an author. Many have suggested his interest and motivation lie in his own agenda, but I would argue that he is playing on the uneducated masses to really debate such a \\"controversial\\" issue with what is purely speculative fiction to line his pockets.<br /><br />Better actor than author...<br /><br />My interest in this subject matter and analytical side in search of concrete data surrounding this matter (that Dan Brown disappointed me with, especially with a weak ending) I did find in a related new book out--<br /><br />Breaking The Da Vinci Code  by Darrell L. Bock, Ph.D.

B000B5IOUW|4.0|The basic idea of \\"The Butterfly Effect\\" appeals to me. I remember the Ray Bradbury short story where the guy goes back in time to shoot a T-Rex and changes the future because he comes back with a butterfly on his boot and enjoyed watching Sam trying to set the past to rights on \\"Quantum Leap.\\" But the story from co-writers and co-directors Eric Bress and J. Mackye Gruber also resonates with me because of an idea I had for short story about a rich guy who wants the Confederacy to win the Civil War. He sits in the time machine trying to select the right moment to go back and change history; he only has one shot and he sits there, going over all the options (e.g., assassinate Lincoln years earlier, help Pickett's charge succeed), unable to decide which would guarantee success.<br /><br />However, in \\"The Butterfly Effect\\" it turns out that Evan (Ashton Kutcher) has multiple opportunities for changing his past, although actally it is the past of Kayleigh Miller (Amy Smart) that he wants to change. But his also means changing the past of Kayleigh's brother, Tommy (William Lee Scott) and their friend, Lenny (Elden Henson), as well as Evan's mother (Melora Walters) and his college roommate (Ethan Suplee). The problem is that every time he changes the past things do not necessarily get better as new problems are presented. But Evan keeps trying to find the magic solution that will set everything to rights, or at least what he thinks would be the best of all possible worlds.<br /><br />Evan and his friends had a trouble childhood. \\"The Butterfly Effect\\" takes place mainly in the present, but it also involves going back to when the kids were 7 and discovered that Mr. Miller (Eric Stolz) was a sicko and when they were 13 and something equally horrible happened. The first time we visit these events we do not know everything that happened because Evan does not remember; as a child he was afflicted with blackouts and since the film is told from his perspective we follow suit. Evan's mother is worried that he might have the same mental illness as his father, but Dr. Redfield (Nathaniel DeVaux) does not think so and has Evan start keeping a journal.<br /><br />In college Evan discovers that when he reads the journal entries he wrote in the past he can go back to that moment in time and that he can control what he says and does, thereby changing the present. This is certainly an interesting way of engaging in time travel (cf. Christopher Reeves thinks his way to the past in \\"Somewhere in Time\\") and I think \\"The Butterfly Effect\\" is a rather ambitious time travel film that is trying to be intelligent in terms of both the theory at work and the construction of the story. This is one of those films where you can better appreciate it the second time around, even if you do all the Infinifilm options, especially once you understand the rules for the game.<br /><br />In the end I am not sure if it is because the intelligence of the story by Bress and Gruber is not up to their ambition, but you cannot fault the effort. One of the strengths of this film is how it takes it time, as Evan wrestles with not only the changes in his world but struggles to figure out what he can do to make everything better the next time around. This is certainly superior to their previous effort, \\"Final Destination 2\\" and it will be interesting to see what they come up with next if they continue along this path. As for performances I would say that Amy Smart's is the best of the bunch and as for Ashton Kutcher, I know he is usually regarded as a tabloid joke or a television pretty boy, but this was actually the first film I have seen when I liked his character or his performance. He might be a forgotten actor by the end of the decade, but he gets props for showing some ambition. But in the final analysis this is Bress and Gruber's film and everybody is just along for the ride.<br /><br />I watched the director's cut (or, I guess, the directors' cut) before seeing the original theatrical ending or the two alternative endings (\\"Stalker\\" and \\"Happy Sappy\\") and at this point would have to say the first one I saw is the best of the bunch. That is because while the effect remains the same the cause in the original theatrical release is just too simplistic after the complicated setup. Granted, the preferred version is rather dark and twisted, but if you listen to any of the commentary on the DVD you will understand their reasoning.g the original theatrical ending or the two alternative endings (\\"Stalker\\" and \\"Happy Sappy\\") and at this point would have to say the first one I saw is the best of the bunch. B000ETQRCM|5.0|People say Pearl Jam is back.  People say that the new album is the best since Vitalogy and reminiscent of Ten.  The truth is that Pearl Jam never left; the core of their music can be discovered on all of their albums if a listener searches hard enough.  While Riot Act and Binaural might not have the beginning-to-end smash hits like Ten, songs like \\"Light Years\\" and \\"Cropduster\\" rank right up there with PJ's best.  The heart of their music lies in the message delivered by the soul-pounding lyrics and the spine-tingling music that accompanies it.   <br /> <br />And with the new album, nothing has changed.  Some reviews say that they released the proper single with \\"World Wide Suicide,\\" which I agree with in terms of mass societal appeal.  But tracks like \\"Unemployed,\\" \\"Life Wasted,\\" and \\"Marker in the Sand\\" are better.   <br /> <br />Of course, writing this review is pointless.  What makes Pearl Jam the best band in the world is that they don't give a shhh about critics.  As long as they keep pumping out stuff that defies convention and the idiotic critics, I'm happy.  So, for those of you who haven't liked anything since Vitalogy, go back and listen to songs like \\"In Hiding,\\" \\"In My Tree,\\" \\"Red Mosquito,\\" Sleight of Hand,\\" \\"Love Boat Captain,\\" \\"MFC,\\" and the two songs mentioned earlier, then tell me that Pearl Jam \\"is back.\\" The truth is they never left. <br />
B000EULJLU|5.0|Alright. I know what you're thinking after the first listen. Where's the hate? Where's the patented Maynard scream? Why are the songs so long? What is going on here?    I'll admit I asked those same questions after the first listen. The build up to this release was intense, and probably got out of control. I heard people saying the upcoming Tool release was going to be the band at its heaviest, that they had been listening to Opeth and Meshuggah, and to expect a merge of those Swedish supergroups. But if you've been listening to Tool as long as I have, you know the band likes to surprise people, it likes to throw curve balls, it doesn't release an album until they believe it is finished, and it produces albums that cannot be figured out with just one listen.    To start, Vicarious, Jambi, The Pot, and Rosetta Stoned are absolute rockers. Yes, maybe a bit too much APC influence on the first track, but did Maynard's other band ever have such blasting riffs, and earthquake-inducing drum beats? All of these heavier songs employ odd time signatures, ones that even for me (a former drummer) are hard to keep up with. And the bass...Justin Chancellor explodes in a number of these tracks. I can't remember really noticing his work as much, on any other Tool album (he did not appear on Opiate or Undertow).    Then there are the typical Tool interim tracks: Lipan Conjuring, Lost Keys (Blame Hofmann), and Viginti Tres. They set the mood, they aren't going to blast a hole in your pants...they are what they are. Were you expecting any past tracks such as these to set the world ablaze (like Intermission, Mantra, Cesaro Summability, Disgustipated)???    And finally, the tracks that seem to be causing the most controversy: Wings for Marie Parts I and II, Intension, and Right In Two. They are all very long. On the first listen, I did find myself anticipating some type of bone-crushing guitar line to pop out of nowhere, and then suddenly, the song was over. GET OVER IT. That is not what this Tool album is about. Once I freed myself of this anticipation, I listened to the album again. And again. And again. In the middle of the second listen, my appreciation grew. By the fourth, I found this to be the third best Tool album ever released - which makes 10,000 Days close to being the third best album ever released. (Aenema and Lateralus are one and two in that order.)    Close followers, and those who understand what Tool means, know that the band is an experience. You don't figure them out right away. They are deceptive. They want you to \\"think for yourself, question authority,\\" to consider other possibilities, to abandon your prejudices. Therefore, your first listen of 10,000 Days will not give you the full story. Maynard's voice is in full form (and you'll find he uses new tonations and distortions this time around), Adam's guitar work cannot be duplicated by any other band (when you hear him, you know it's Adam, sort of like Piggy (RIP) of Voivod, Alex Lifeson of Rush, and even Tommy Victor of Prong). We've already mentioned Justin, and as for Danny...is anyone with a knowledge of percussion out there not floored by how every swipe of his two arms is heard, and felt? His sticks could reverse the blood flow in your arteries.    You were expecting Lateralus 2? You didn't get it. Aenima 2? Undertow 2? Opiate 2? Just think: each of those albums was different in their own right. Tool is a progression. 10,000 Days is the Tool of today. Maynard doesn't hate anymore (at least not as much). There are no Hookers with Penises, there are no Jerk-Offs that need to be shot in the f**** head... The major clue here is Maynard's dedicating the album's title and two tracks to his late mother. (You already know this, right? A stroke paralyzed her, and she died...drum roll...roughly 27 years, or roughly 10,000 days later.)    By the way, Tool probably goes to greater lengths to preserve their music, and keep it out of the hands of free-wheeling downloaders, than anyone else. Buy the CD. If not because the band is owed for its work, purchase 10,000 Days because of the fabulous artwork, and stereo-scopic lenses in the package.    It may be years before everyone fully appreciates this release. I guess that's what happens, when you're a band that is so far ahead of everyone else.

B000A176VU|3.0|I recently read Night Over Water and Pillars in the Earth and was taken by the lush ease into which Follett pulls his readers into his stories. So when I picked up Eye of the Needle, I was both kind of hoping it would be as good as the two previously mentioned books while at the same time feeling that no way could it live up to the high standards I was now placing Follett fare.<br /><br />Sadly, Eye of the Needle is a bit of a mess in my opinion. From the get go it jumps around from one scene to the next with little in the way of transition. So though time is going by quickly at times, it is a little startling to find out several pages into a chapter that months have transpired when you think what you are reading is taking place only hours later. This is a very short book in comparison to Night over Water and a short story in comparison to Pillars in the Earth. And I think that it suffers a little because in all honesty, this might be the most complicated of the three stories. I wish that Follett had been a little more comfortable and taken his time fleshing out events, plots,and places.<br /><br />This book is not a total disaster. You will come up against a myriad of familiar Follettisms. The characters area formed much like they are in other books so it will feel almost like you know them. Lusty scenes pop up every fifty pages like clockwork, and the writing is vintage Follett. If you love his books, this is not one to shy away from. But if this might be your first Follett experience, I would say \\"look for Pillars in the Earth instead. I guarantee you a better, more satisfying page turner.\\"
