B00005JNRY|4.0|A little known secret about Pixar, is their huge support for their local community.  Last night I attended a fund raiser premier of CARS at Pixar's studio's in Emeryville CA.  The event raised over $80,000 for our local school district!    So here are my thoughts on the movie.    Firstly, this is a fast paced and LOUD movie.  Those with sensitive ears should think about taking cotton buds to the theater.    Ok, I read some of the comments so far based on the teaser's and have to say that the animated cars are done wonderfully.  Each car really has it's own personality and although they do look a little cartoonish, Pixar has again shown that they can animate anything and bring it to life and then some.    The big race scenes are really only at the very beginning and at the very end, the majority of the movie is set in a small town \\"Radiator Springs\\" somewhere in the midwest just off Route 66.      I won't give too much away as far as the story goes, you'll need to go see it yourself for that.    The movie is packed full of very funny jokes and scenes, like the Tractor Tipping scene, and the SUV off-road bootcamp!    Visually, this movie is stunning.  I can't imagine the amount of research that went into producing this one.  Anyone who has driven I-40 near Amarillo TX will recognise the mountain ranges shaped like old Cadillac's burried nose down in the sand.  They really capture the road trip experience.  And the scenery is breath-taking.    Not being a big fan of \\"Larry The Cable Guy\\" I have to say that his performance as Mater the tow truck, was brilliant.  As one of the main characters, he was very funny and endearing.    Technically, Pixar really pushed the envelope again.  We're used to Pixar movies breaking ground in each movie, the underwater rendering in Finding Nemo, the fur rendering in Monsters Inc., etc.. In cars, it's all about the rendering of dust particles which looks super realistic and is not an easy thing to achieve.      Overall, this movie will have great appeal to a lot of people, although I personally think that The Incredibles is still my favorite.  This one might not win the Best Animated Feature award but I'm sure it will get awards for the technical aspects of the film.    Finally, I just want to thank Pixar once again for their amazing and continued support to the local community, whether it be fund raising events like last nights, or the masses of computers they donate to the schools, or the number of their employee's that regularly volunteer their freetime to work with the kids in mentoring programs.  I couldn't wish for a better neighbor.

It does not matter what your political views may be, the passion and lyrical precision as well as the amazing harmonies from The Indigo Girls make this song fill the void left in pop music from superficial songs that have been released lately. The album is built around the idea of having each song have a different all-around sound, which works pretty well. I liked \\"Missundaztood\\" and this is right up there; because of its daring nature, impressive vocals, and personal lyricism.  <br /> <br />Best Songs: \\"Dear Mr. President,\\" \\"I Got Money Now,\\" \\"Runaway,\\" \\"The One That Got Away\\"

Anyway, Ashley more than makes up for Justine's absence and appears on what I consider to currently be the best vocal trance track of the year thus far. <br /> <br />As for the male vocal tracks, I believe they are all by the same guy who sings on Alone Tonight.  I don't care for his voice at all, which makes me not like any of these tracks.   <br /> <br />For the most part, a very good artist album, which seems to be hard to come by lately in trance.  Just don't expect an upbeat dance floor type mix, because you'd have to go to their previous mix CD's for that.  This is something very different, but very good.

B000ETQRCM|5.0|I'll start off by saying I'm a huge PJ fan.  Have been since 9th grade when I bought \\"Ten\\" and listened to it the whole way from MO to FL on family vacation...then the whole time I was there...then the whole way back. <br /> <br />This album gives me the same feeling I had then.  And it's the first time in a long time.  In the past 15 years, I've phased out radio completely, and then, as I grew older, became remoter from college and hip friends, I've been exposed to less and less good music.  PJ is one of my consistent, buy-sight-unseen every new album, bands, but none of them in the past 10 years has captivated me the way this self-titled record does. <br /> <br />\\"Marker in the Sand\\" is the standout track, in my opinion.  Lyrically and musically it is profound, beautiful, and mixed-up.  It's the first song I've listened to on repeat since that depressive \\"Purple Rain\\" episode in college.  It's indicative of many of the tracks on this album, though, in that it mixes \\"traditional\\" PJ sounds: melodic ballad, hard wall of guitar, unexpected Gossard/Mccready exchanges, and sublime Vedder lyrics.  At first it sounds pretty hard-rocking and angry, enabling the melodic beauty of the chorus to hit you like a ton of bricks right in the chest.  And, the beauty of Eddie Vedder's writing: the lyrics fit the music perfectly.  The plaintive, \\"God, what do you say?  I'm calling out,\\" is the first time a rock song has made me cry in a long, long time.  Let's be honest, since \\"Alive.\\" <br /> <br />Though I agree with and admire PJ's politics, \\"Army Reserve\\" is a little too literal for my taste, though, again, the melody and musicality of this track is gorgeous.  Every other track on the album is amazing.  \\"Parachutes\\" reminds me of a White Album-era Beatles song in its simplicity and depth.  \\"Life Wasted\\" is a life-affirming, rocking, melodic anthem in the tradition of \\"I Am Mine\\" and \\"Come Back\\" is just sweetly, plaintively addictive. <br /> <br />McCready's lyrics on \\"Inside Job\\"are so raw and true and real.  I guess he's proven himself worthy on many levels, aside from the rock-guitar-god inspirer of the frat-boy \\"McCready\\" chants at all their live shows.  ;-) <br /> <br />Speaking of live shows, critics have been hailing this album as a \\"comeback,\\" but fans of PJ know them now primarily as a touring band and their live shows have done nothing but improve. <br /> <br />I'm seeing them for the third time on May 13 and I look forward to it as the religious experience it has been, and I know will be, for me.  The only difference this time is that I'll really be ROOTING for tracks off the new album, especially \\"Marker in the Sand.\\"  I know someone mentioned \\"Come Back\\" as the new \\"Yellow Ledbetter,\\" but for me it's \\"Marker in the Sand.\\"
B000EULJLU|5.0|There was a lot of hype and speculation surrounding the Tool album that became '10,000 Days'.  They are not the most prolific band in the world but they do have a reputation for excellence and the ability to constantly deliver the goods on every level.  The combination of these things made for a tense five-year wait for Tool fans but the album that resulted was worth every minute of that wait. <br /> <br />Obviously, the first thing I noticed about the album was the cover art.  It, much like the band, is instantly engrossing and completely unique.  I could have been preoccupied by it for hours, had I not wanted to hear the album so badly.  One of the band's trademarks is the time and attention they pay to the cover art, and '10,000 Days' is no exception.  It is challenging, to say the very least and there's no real way to describe it without seeing it for yourself. <br /> <br />Anyway, Tool's last album 'Lateralus', was a masterpiece of progressive rock that would be difficult to equal.  That being said, '10,000 Days' is an album coming from a completely different space so it would be unfair to compare the two.  'Lateralus' was ominous and meditative.  To me, it felt like it was coming from another planet and its true impact kind of crept up on the listener.  The spacey feel that 'Lateralus' had to it meant that there was plenty of room for contemplation.   <br /> <br />'10,000 Days', however, has a completely different kind of impact.  Right from the opening seconds, it hits you with a kind of anger and ferocity that hasn't been seen since the band's early work.  It is clear from the album's lyrical content (particularly songs like 'Vicarious') that the band is unhappy with the state of the world at the moment.  '10,000 Days' has some of the most overtly political material that Tool has written in years.  That open and honest anger is continued throughout the record.   <br /> <br />The new attitude of the band, however, does not sacrifice the complexity and attention to detail that we are used to hearing from Tool in a musical sense.  Musically, Tool is just as stunning as ever.  The complex instrumental passages, changes in tempo and dynamics and virtuosity are still present; there is just a heavy, dark edge to the music that we have not seen since the beginning of Tool's career.   <br /> <br />This new, revitalised band has managed to achieve the perfect marriage of musical complexly and outrage.  Tool just keeps getting better.
0553573403|5.0|Picked this book at random one day in a bookstore and I'm very glad I did. This is the first volume in a series of books called A Song Of Ice And Fire. Not really knowing what to expect as I don't read too much fantasy, though The Lord Of The Rings I still consider the best work of fiction I've ever read, this book overwhelmed me. It has a wonderful combination of action, intrigue, heartbreak, plus a wealth of characters from the very good to the unbelievably evil. I've since read all the other published installments and am eagerly awaiting the next. While Martin does jump around a bit because of all the characters and their sub-plots, it's not hard at all to keep up with the various developments. One aspect I really love is that just when you think a character is about to get out of a particular debacle, it only gets worse. What a change from the usual 'everything comes out okay at the end'.<br /><br />  This is loosely based on the Wars Of The Roses, so if you have any interest in that period of history, this is the book for you. Although in the fantasy genre, there's not a lot of use of magic or non-human beings, but when they are used, it's very important, such as dragons and special weapons. Since the series has been written over a span of ten years or so, the characters change, mature, develop different mind sets due to events - much like all of us. I wish I had discovered Martin sooner, he's become one of my favorite writers. I highly recommend this book and the series overall.

0553579908|4.0|Have you ever been weary of seeing a sequel because you know it will not be nearly as good as the original? Or have you been hesitant to see a something a second time because you just know it will not be as good as it was the first time? I have. And that is how I felt as I tried to talk myself into reading A Clash of Kings. At a time when I was struggling to find any books that I was enthusiastic about, I read the first of this 4-(so far)-part series, A Game of Thrones. I enjoyed it so thoroughly I was hesitant to read the second installment. I was skeptical. The book could not be as good, I thought. The book will tarnish the near perfect reputation of its predecessor, I told myself. That is not fair, I reasoned. And I decided that it was time to read the second book. <br /> <br />To be fair, A Clash of Kings is not as good as A Game of Thrones. From a chronological standpoint I feel that it would essentially be impossible for the second book to be as good as or better than the first. The first was the introduction; everything was new. In the second book, though there is still more to introduce and many things are new, the story continues. And there is much more to come.  <br /> <br />I apologize if this comparison carries a negative connotation, because it is not my intent. Book two of the A Song of Ice and Fire series by George R. R. Martin, in my opinion bears a resemblance to J. R. R. Tolkien's The Two Towers (also the second book of its series). Both books have \\"set-up\\" roles. A lot happens without anything happening, if you follow what I am saying. The pieces are put into place in these books, and they are poised for action in the book(s) to come. That is not to say that there is any lack of action in A Clash of Kings. Far from it, rather. The story is ready to pounce. Book three, A Storm of Swords, should be a thrill ride. <br /> <br />I am still fascinated by the chapter style. Through the entire series George R. R. Martin chooses a handful of characters andeach chapter is from the perspective of one of them. Readers are able to be essentially omniscient in the realm of the Seven Kingdoms by seeing the trials and tribulations of characters good and bad, here and there. The book is a series of cliffhangers and it makes the suspense pleasurable is a strange masochistic sort of way. The tension will build and build and then just as it nears its apex, the chapter ends. The action picks up from that point...or not...a few chapters later. It sounds more frustrating than fun, but when you read the books it is actually fun and not frustrating. It also makes the books easier to get through. You will fly through a few chapters to get to the next part about whatever character you are following.  <br /> <br />I know that sci-fi/fantasy books are daunting. They seem to all be 700-1100 pages and most are but one piece of a multi-part series. It makes for a lot of reading because by taking the first you may be signing yourself up to read an entire series. I feel the same way and I just try to space the books out so it does not seem as bad. I have a decent memory and found that even though I read the first book almost eight months ago, I was able to pick up right where the story left off. I did not have to re-acclimate myself with the story. This was important because the author does not take time to recap what happened in the previous book. There is a lot of detail and it would make a long book even longer to go through it all.  <br /> <br />I do not read many books in this genre, but I truly get excited about these books. I loved A Clash of Kings and I loved A Game of Thrones before it. I look forward to continuing this series.

1594200823|5.0|This is one of those rare books that gets a person thinking seriously about topics not usually pondered:  How has our food system, in just a few decades, developed into today's industrial, factory-fed, subsidized corn-based model?  What are the costs and consequences of the model?  Who pays them? Why is our system usually portrayed as the only viable means to feed ourselves?  Who's in control?  Is organic any better?   <br /> <br />\\"Dilemma\\" is engaging and readable, the type of book you'll find yourself mentioning and recommending to friends, even if you're among the majority of Americans (like me) who puts more thought into the gas we put into our cars than the food we put into our mouths.   <br /> <br />There are indictments here of the industrial food system, the politics, special interests, and marketers that brought the system to its dominate role, and the price-obsessed consumer who buys into the system asking no questions.  There's also a clear explanation that gives many of us our first awareness of how petroleum-dependent our food system is.  We are, in a real sense, eating petroleum when we eat many food products because synthetic fertilizers and pesticides are manufactured from oil and gas.  <br /> <br />The book also gives insights into the environmental costs today's over-fertilized, monospeciatic, concentrated feed-lot systems have on the land, water, and air.  It's not a pretty picture.  And the questions Pollan raises about animal ethics are important, leading the reader to ask himself whether choices I make in the grocery are consistent with my views on how animals should be treated.  For example, the usual supermarket egg is produced by a chicken that \\"lives\\" its entire productive life in a horrendous cramped cage.  Just so we can buy eggs for 79 cents/dozen.   <br /> <br />This book was a pleasure to read.  Even if it turns out that all the numbers he cites arn't exactly accurate, or that there are other views to counter the points he makes (andthere are), there's a lot here to get one thinking, and maybe change the way we make our food choices.   <br /> <br />The only flaws I would mention are that it could've benefited from better editing to tighten it up, especially the foraging section.  One chapter includes at least twenty quotes from a philosopher of hunting.  Enough! And there is a place or two that the same points are repeated.   <br /> <br />All in all an important book.   <br /> <br />

0345423496|3.0|Clarke returns to the universe of 2001: A Space Odyssey with the fourth and last novel, this time focusing on Frank Poole, the astronaut murdered by Hal in 2001.  A thousand years later, Poole's frozen corpse is retrieved and revived by a society that regards him as a hero and a living national treasure. At first he's fully occupied with learning to live in an alien society and providing information to historians. But as boredom sets in, he finds himself drawn back to space and the Jupiter system... and the possibility of a meeting with David Bowman.<br /><br />As Clarke notes in an afterword, it's not possible to be completely consistent in a series about the near future  that was written over a period of thirty years, and this book  is better viewed as a variation on a theme rather than a sequel. With that in mind, the within series continuity glitches aren't an issue, although there are a couple of annoying glitches within the book's own timeline. The real problem is that this book is mostly a travelogue of the year 3001, with the section about the monoliths feeling sketchy and tacked on. There's also a problem with some blatant preaching in places, when characters who are supposed to be having a conversation sound more as if they're reading a prepared speech to sway an audience. I found it annoying, and I agree with many of the views being espoused.<br /><br />It's a readable and often enjoyable book, but I expect better from Clarke. I'd have felt cheated if I'd spent the money to buy this in hardback.

For example, look at the footnote to 1 Corinthians 3:15 that denies the doctrine of Purgatory finding a basis in this passage of scripture--a passage that has been proposed, dogmatically, as a \\"proof text\\" for the doctrine of Purgatory!  A blasphemous treatment of Catholic scripture!    However, after reading Pope Leo XIII's \\"Providentissimus Deus\\" alongside Vatican II's \\"Dei Verbum,\\" with the latter full of practical loopholes and near-wholesale departures from Traditional Catholic teaching on Sacred Scripture, it's easy, frightful and saddening to see why and how the NAB went awry to the obvious extreme(s) evident to orthodox Catholics.      Having been too often disappointed and infuriated with the faithless, \\"dynamically\\" translated NAB, I opted instead for the faithful, literally translated Douay-Rheims Bible, painstakingly derived from the Latin Vulgate, the Bible declared to be a sure, inerrant norm for Catholic docrine by the Council of Trent.  The D-R provides a firm and unabashed foundation for Traditional Roman Catholic doctrine, something seriously lacking in the NAB and generally ignored by the hierarchy of the steeply backsliding \\"Euro-\\" and \\"Am-\\" churches (which have shamelessly and publicly abandoned their Roman Catholic heritage).    The NAB (suitable for liberal Protestants, not orthodox Catholics), together with the abuse-ridden Novus Ordo Mass and the awful English translations of the New Roman Missal and the Liturgy of the Hours, constitute a multi-pronged, all-out attack on Roman Catholic Tradition and orthodoxy, waged squarely upon the \\"lex orandi, lex credendi\\" front.      May Our Lord and Our Lady help us, as we pray and do penance for the mess the Church finds herself in!

Another reviewer pointed out that this album is not a huge departure from the sound of Lateralus, which is true.  My feeling about Lateralus, while still a great album, it seemed that they were diving into fresh territory and had not fully honed their skills.  Much like Undertow before Aenima.  This album is skillfully put together just as Aenima, but also contains the experimental wanderings that propelled Lateralus to such heights.  I would have given it 5 stars, but I would have liked to see them take it a little further, but this is still a rock solid album from a rock solid band and any fan of Tool's music should not listen to the other reviews and buy 10,000 Days!  Hell, it's worth the price for the packaging alone.

B000EULJLU|5.0|My introduction to Tool came some years ago, when I first heard \\"Schism\\". Having been listening to Iron Maiden, Dream Theater, et al. before then, I wasn't a stranger to the genre, and I clicked immediately. After acquiring \\"Lateralus\\" and listening through it thouroughly, I bought Opiate, Aenima and Undertow, which gave me an odd, backwards perspective of the band's evolution.    After some deliberation, I found Lateralus to be the best Tool album at that time, with the band showing far more rounded musicianship, not to mention the superior production of the album. Aenima and Undertow, in retrospect, sounded almost crude in comparison.    Well, that now applies to Lateralus as well. With 10,000 Days, Tool push themselves further into the Progressive realm, giving their new album a far richer, denser sound, with a decidedly international flavour. Their tempestuous, lurching sound is now layered with nearly Eno-esque droning and swooping in the background, giving the music an enveloping, monumental sound, a very entrancing experience. Keenen's crisper, more emotional vocals are a highly welcome evolution here.    Add to this the fact that the musicianship and production go over and above that of Lateralus, and you have a solid, most impressive album from a band known for its ambivalence towards trends, and perhaps even its fans. They have forged ahead with their vision, and I'm loving every minute of the ride.
B000040OBS|4.0|Alan Vega and Martin Rev were WAAAY ahead of their time. Though their debut wasn't officially released until '78 (and even then, it predated the debuts of Joy Division, Killing Joke, The Cure, and possibly even PiL by about a year or so), this guitarless NY duo had been around since '71.<br /><br />Anyway this album is the genesis of post-punk/New Wave, performed with a beat-up organ/synthesizer Rev probably found in the back alley of a music shop, and a decrepit but chugging drum machine that brings a futuristic pulse to the eerie synths and Alan Vega's voice, which sounds like Elvis detained in Guantanomo. Very original, very creepy, and very cool.<br /><br />The material varies from what would be otherwise poppy tracks made slightly unnerving due to their foreboding starkness (Girl, Cheree, Keep Your Dreams) to more haunting and atmospheric songs (Ghost Rider, Rocket USA, Che) and even one track that sounds a bit like a primitive Doors cut (I Remember).<br /><br />Then there's the 10-minute Frankie Teardrop--perhaps one of the most terrifying and claustrophobic songs ever released, with Vega's banshee screams punctuating the narrative of a young factory worker who kills himself and his own family out of desperation and wakes up in hell. The conclusion, with its ominous synths and Vega sounding as if he's going insane from the horror around him, will leave a scar on your mind.<br /><br />The bonus material includes a decent, if roughly recorded CBGB's performance and the confrontational and chaotic \\"23 Minutes Over Brussels\\" show which is important for historical reasons, I suppose, but isn't worth listening to more than once or twice. The first disc is all you need to know. A bit primitive and dated in places, but still vital, influential, and amazing for fans of the genre.

Opeth seems to have turned away from the more atmospheric sound to show their expert musicianship. Even though 'My Arms Your Hearse' is and will always be my favorite Opeth album, 'Ghost Reveries' is essentual to every Opeth fan.

0743454537|1.0|First, a disclaimer: I usually stick to classic, critically-acclaimed novels.  I rarely read authors who monopolize a genre with one serially-produced formula (although I did read \\"The Shining\\" when I was eleven) and so I admit that Jodi Picoult's family dramas are not my normal fare.  However, I was intrigued by the premise of \\"My Sister's Keeper\\" and encouraged by some good reviews.  When it was chosen by my book club, I was excited to read it and completely open to enjoying it.<br /><br />Unfortunately, this is one of the most inane things I have ever read.  The legal battle takes off before the characters are developed (and don't hold your breath - they never obtain that crucial third dimension), precluding emotional investment on either side.  The main character's motivation for taking such drastic action is not satisfactorily explained, either.  Of course the reader can infer why she feels the way she does about her situation but I could have gotten that much from reading the back cover; I expect a little more insight when I take the time to read the novel.<br /><br />Cookie cutter characters and timing issues aside, Picoult's choppy and unimaginative writing does not help.  She rarely tends toward the figurative (but not in the good, Samuel Beckett kind of way) and her rare incursions into poesy are contrived.  The phrase \\"a sluice of a boy,\\" for example, just barely makes sense and made me wonder where the humanoid streamlet's flood valve was located.  Also, please be aware that Picoult's standard gimmick is rotating narrators and that each character has their own typeface - it's totally obnoxious.<br /><br />OK, that's enough ranting.  I'm just disappointed that a premise with such rich potential ended up reading like a screenplay for an episode of \\"Law and Order\\" and I really wanted to spare people from reading this.  Instead, I'd recommend Atul Gawande's best-selling \\"Complications\\" if you're looking for musings on medical ethics.  Or \\"The Corrections\\" by Jonathan Franzen excels in recreating believable family dysfunction.  With books like those out there, there is no excuse for wasting your time with \\"My Sister's Keeper.\\"  Happy reading!ions\\" by Jonathan Franzen excels in recreating believable family dysfunction.  With books like those out there, there is no excuse for wasting your time with \\"My Sister's Keeper.\\"  Happy reading!
B000EULJLU|3.0|You know, Tool have become extremely adept at making fascinating songs that stretch for upwards of 14 minutes, infusing their albums with intriguing, brief interludes, and having an uncommonly strong equilibrium between intelligent lyrics, varied vocals, and instrumental innovation.  While their earlier efforts (\\"Opiate\\" and \\"Undertow\\") now seem painfully juvenile, doing cartwheels to try to draw attention to themselves (reaching their pretentious peak with the ridiculously long 'Disgustipated'), their subsequent efforts now shine that much more.  \\"Aenima\\" was incredibly varied, challenging, and compulsively listenable; \\"Lateralus\\" housed some of the most layered, intricate, and intelligent songs to fall under the label of 'heavy metal.'  Five years later, \\"10,000 Days\\" dips back into the \\"Lateralus\\"' pot for an album that feels largely recycled, from the guitar riffs to percussion; in all fairness, Tool has carried certain 'signature sounds' from album to album, but when I hear tracks heavy with the influence of 'Stinkfist' or 'The Grudge,' I begin to wonder if the band is just lying down on the job because they can afford to.  The familiarity of much of the album would be a bit more forgivable if the charismatic and challenging performance of vocalist Maynard James Keenan were more pronounced; but unlike Tool's previous efforts, the frontman's voice is, for the most part, pushed behind the instrumentation (this could very well be because his lyrics contain 1/8 of the creativity they had before...even his APC work is superior to this drivel).  Therefore, what we're left with in \\"10,000 Days\\" is a very thinly-veiled sequel to \\"Lateralus,\\" and depending on your appraisal of that album (mine happened to be very favorable), you might be able to excuse a lot of the creative impotence at 'work' here.  The album itself is highly listenable, with songs that don't possess the structural tightness of those on \\"Lateralus,\\" but sound well enough ('Vicarious,' 'Jambi,' '10,000 Days,' and 'Right in Two' are fine examples).  The album also contains some of the most creative packaging and artwork I've ever seen (and by itself would merit the sticker price).  I think the crux of my disappointment in \\"10,000 Days\\" is that, overall, \\"it's a good album,\\" but it wouldn't have taken a lot to make it \\"that much better.\\"Days,' and 'Right in Two' are fine examples).  The album also contains some of the most creative packaging and artwork I've ever seen (and by itself would merit the sticker price).  I think the crux of my disappointment in \\"10,000 Days\\" is that, overall, \\"it's a good album,\\" but it wouldn't have taken a lot to make it \\"that much better.\\"

1594200823|5.0|This book is both well-written and thought-provoking, without being preachy.  The author points out that Americans have become disconnected from their food sources.  Everything just materializes in the grocery store and is consumed without a thought as to where the food comes from, or the impact that our consumption of that food has on ourselves and the rest of the planet.  The author examines the origins of a McDonald's meal, an Organic Meal, an integrated Farm Raised Meal and a Hunter-Gatherer Meal and tries to trace the impacts of each.  Although I grew up on a farm myself and hunted for food when I was young, I'd almost forgotten the ramifications of my dietary choices.  This book elegantly reminded me of things I had almost forgotten.  Is a chicken raised on a farm where it is free to roam better for you and the world than one raised and slaughtered in an industrial farm?  Is it ethical to eat meat at all?  How should we consider the use of petroleum in terms of the global cost of raising corn?<br /><br />This book is not about telling you what you should and should not eat.  It is about allowing yourself to develop your own answers to questions that many don't want to think about.  This is the best book I've read this year.

B000EULJLU|4.0|I can't quite wrap my head around this album yet. It's very similar to Aenima and moreso Lateralus in technique and style, and yet it's very different in it's level of emotion and depth.    This is the most personal album by Tool to date. When Maynard sings \\"Give me my wings!\\" on \\"10,000 days (Wings pt. 2),\\" a song about his late mother Judith Marie, you can't help but feel his soul crying out. Maynard, largely considered agnostic, even eludes to a higher being on \\"Right in Two\\" with lines such as \\"Why did father give these humans free will/Now they're all confused.\\"    No longer are Tool singing about Saturn return and other intellectually centered material. While this makes the album more down to earth, it strips Tool of the aura of uncertainty and mystery that always attracted me to them.    This is also arguably Tool's most primal album. The opening riff to \\"Jambi\\" suggests a bare bones, stripped approach to song writing that permeates throughout the entire track and much of the album. On Rosetta Stoned, Maynard sings \\"[...]\\" like a primate just released from captivity.    The problem I'm having with 10,000 Days is that, while I do enjoy it, I don't get lost in it like I do with Aenima, Lateralus, or even Undertow. It doesn't take me to \\"another world,\\" for lack of a less cliche term. But maybe that will come with time.    And yet, the individual songs are excellent. \\"Right in Two\\" builds up to a dramatic crescendo, resulting in one of the best songs in Tool's canon. \\"The Pot,\\" another highlight, calls back to the days of \\"Opiate\\" with Maynard showcasing his true tenor voice in front of a groove-heavy rhythm section. The already mentioned \\"10,000 days\\" is extremely dramatic and dare I say...emotional.    Hence my confusion.    I've read many of the reviews, and many times I can't help but discredit half of what's being said. Many who loved their past efforts are saying the album is utter crap, which is probably a little drastic. However, I wouldn't consider thisa gigantic step forward for Tool - maybe a step to the right would be more appropriate.

B000EULJLU|5.0|I usually lurk in the \\"underground\\" as it were, largely ignoring the mainstream, but I always make an exception for the incredibly popular and revered Tool.  They have been blowing my mind for years with each succesive album. When a new one hits, its not a new release, its a f*cking EVENT.<br /><br />  That being said, I was suprised by all the negative pre-buzz surrounding this album. People were complaining it didn't \\"sound like Tool\\" and it was nothing but \\"boring filler\\". I could not disagree more. As many people have pointed out, each Tool release is distinct in its sound and scope. Opiate, Undertow, Anemia, and Lateralus all sound fairly different from each other. Sure there are similarities and a trademark \\"style\\".. they're all from the same band! Now with 10,000 Days, Tool again has something different and altogether brilliant. The opener Vicarious is classic Tool, complete with complex time signatures, cynical lyrics, and awesome intensity. From there, its track after track of great listening. The track that stands out to me is \\"Wings Part I and II\\". This one really long track is perhaps one of the most intense and powerful pieces of music ever produced in modern rock. No, you can't bang your head to it. There are no crushing riffs or pummeling drums. Just Maynard calmly paying homage to his dead mother over a brooding bass line and rolling thunder. The song slowly builds to an unbelievable climax that is gauranteed to raise the hairs on your neck and make you appreciate the sheer genuis of this song. Beautiful and chilling. My only gripe on this disc is Lipan Conjuring, just because it seems out of place. Of course, this is probably exactly what Tool wanted to do, so in that case... uh, good job! So in the end, yes, 10,000 Days sounds different from any Tool album that has come out, and I think thats a great thing. This is an awesome album for any Tool fan or music lover. Just give it a chance and it will give you back a LOT more.<br /><br />P.S. On a sidenote, the packaging is hands down the most awesome thing I've ever gotten \\"free\\" with an album. Really really cool. (And I'm not even high!)packaging is hands down the most awesome thing I've ever gotten \\"free\\" with an album. Really really cool. (And I'm not even high!)

0743424425|5.0|I read this many years ago but still vividly remember a lot of it because of the great story. This really is one of King's best if not THE best. Just fantastic!!  <br /> <br />The setting, the Overlook Hotel, an old hotel/resort abandoned for the winter, is perfect for what King does, giving people the creeps. He slowly builds the suspense as Jack, the main character, slowly goes crazy and we as the readers get to watch this unfold. I was never quite sure whether all that Jack sees is really happening, as in ghostly voices, or just his slowly eroding mind losing its grip.  <br /> <br />As the story continues, King draws it out just enough to keep the pace moving while you wait for the other shoe to drop on this unsuspecting caretaker family. I dont want to give away too much of the story but suffice it to say that every page has the potential to make you clench up just a little more and a little more.  <br /> <br />The background story of the Overlook is storytelling at its best, creepy and disturbing. The characters are well done, which is typical for King, and the ending was great. Overall I consider one of the best examples of horror-writing that I'ver read. Recommended for anyone who likes disturbing, provocative fiction written by a master. <br /> <br />

B000ETQRCM|5.0|...about the intensity of emotion and devotion that Pearl Jam still elicits. <br /> <br />I grabbed the single - WWS and Unemployable - as soon as it came out, and I got a pre-release copy of the album about two weeks ago.  As many others have said, you have to listen to this album a few times.  Like all the best music, it comes at you from oblique angles.  It's more nuanced, and less \\"catchy\\", than some of PJ's early work.  I felt the same way about \\"Yield\\", and that album has become one of my all-time favorites. <br /> <br />I guess I'm not your typical PJ fan.  I was only vaguely familiar with their music until four or five years ago.  My sons and their friends would ocassionally jam and when they'd play a PJ tune I'd ask \\"who is that, who did that tune?\\"  It wasn't until about 18 months ago that I finally decided to really check them out.  Yield was the first PJ album to grab me, largely on the strength of \\"In Hiding\\" and \\"Faithful.\\"  I was going through a very difficult time in my life - very alienated - and \\"In Hiding\\" just struck me like a lightning bolt.  Songs about alienation are a rock staple, but I still maintain that \\"In Hiding\\" is the greatest song about alienation ever recorded. <br /> <br />I quickly acquired every PJ album available and started seriously evaluating them.  Oddly, \\"Ten\\" - which so many PJ fans (including my sons) revere and consider their best - didn't really grab me.  There are many good tunes on the album but I didn't like the production.  The sound was somehow muted; it didn't have the sonic vibrancy I'd heard on Yield or No Code.  While many of the tunes on Ten are among my favorites I almost always listen to live versions of them. <br /> <br />What's extraordinary about these guys is that songs that didn't grab you the first five or six times you heard them will then start growing on you.  It's happening to me all over again with this album.  Songs like \\"Gone\\" and \\"Unemployable\\" immediately appealed to me, but it's taken numerouslistenings for songs like \\"Army Reserve\\", \\"Severed Hand\\" and \\"Come Back\\" to make a strong impression.  I'm gonna give away my age here, but I've got to say that it was the same way with a lot of the best Beatles and Stones stuff.  They both did catchy stuff, up-beat rockers that grabbed you right away, and also stuff that was somehow more complex and took time to make sense aurally. <br /> <br />For those of you that love this album, I'm with ya - this is a keeper. For those of you that don't, don't give up on it yet.  Give it a few more listens.  For those of you waiting for \\"Ten\\" again, it just may be that \\"Ten\\" was the right album, at the right time for you, at the right stage of your life, and the music and your sensibilities just won't come together like that with this album. <br /> <br />Whatever you want to say, you have to give Eddie and Mike and Stone and Jeff and Matt credit for still going pretty strong after 15 years.  The Beatles were over by then, and the Stones, Who and Zeppelin were in steep decline by the time they'd been around this long.  For my money U2 has also grown pretty soft in recent years - they can still occasionally rock, but there's too much mushy Bono material.  But after 15 years Eddie and the boys can still pin your ears back with rock 'n roll that hits you right in the gut.  It's pretty amazing. <br /> <br />Get the album. <br /> <br />P.S.  The politics are great, too.  Bush is a warmongering jerk, and PJ calls him out.

B000B8QEYC|5.0|Enya's music has always been uniquely Enya, not just Celtic or Classical or New Age, but just simply Enya. Though some consider her to be repititve or predictable, to me, she is just simply revisting old themes, a practice very notable in the Brennan family, as Clannad and Moya Brennan have also frequently revisted themes and sounds in their music. Roma Ryan's lyrics are very imaginative and invoke the power of creativty. There is a strong Celtic quality with songs like \\"Less than a Pearl\\", \\"The River Sings\\", and \\"Long Long Journey\\". \\"Long Long Journey\\" creates the image of the Irish imigrating to America with it's hymnal/folk song quality. There's even a Celtic ballad quality with \\"If I could be where you are\\" and \\"A Moment Lost\\". Songs like \\"It's In the Rain\\" and \\"Someone Said Goodbye\\" even have a bit of a pop quality. Roma's lyrics once again ask life questions like in \\"Amarantine\\". The beauty of \\"Amarantine\\" really floats in the air witht he innocence of Enya's voice and the smoothness of the strings. Roma's words tell great stories and use symbolism, creating what the listener can emotionally relate to. \\"Sumiregusa\\" is a world of enchantment on its own, creating a beautiful image of nature through the Japanese prose. Perhaps the most amazing song of all is \\"Water Shows the Hidden Heart\\" when it comes down to Enya's vocal variety, style, melody and harmony, and the power of the story in the lyrics. Once again, her multi-vocal methods create beautiful choral sounds. The sci-fi story behind Roma's Loxian lyrics certainly transports the listener into one's own magical world. \\"Drifting\\" provides a nice peaceful interlude. My only criticism would be that I think the album doesn't have the same high quality as her albums from pre-Paint the Sky with Stars, which I also felt with A Day Without Rain, but nonetheless, a lot of the same power remains. Just as with her previous albums, the songs on Amarantine sound like music that you've heard before on a dream, another power that I am convinced runs in the great Brennan family. Amarantine is still a five-star-ranking quality album, which I am convinced Enya will always be.

B000EHSVOG|5.0|Irwin Allen had already one hit disaster epic under his belt (1972's \\"The Poseidon Adventure\\"), and he followed that up with 1974's \\"The Towering Inferno\\", which I thought was an even better movie. \\"The Towering Inferno\\" is about the tallest skyscraper in the world that starts burning out of control after bad wiring causes a flare-up in a storage room. I was scared to death when I watched this film the first couple of times on TV when I was a kid. It doesn't scare me today, but now I find the movie exciting, suspenseful, and mind-boggling. Like \\"The Poseidon Adventure\\", Allen got a big name cast to participate in the film. Paul Newman, Steve McQueen, William Holden, Faye Dunaway, Fred Astaire, Jennifer Jones, Robert Wagner, Robert Vaughn, Richard Chamberlain, Susan Blakely, and O.J. Simpson star, with early film appearances by Dabney Coleman (of \\"9 to 5\\" and TV's \\"Buffalo Bill\\") and Susan Flannery (Emmy winning star of the soap opera \\"The Bold and the Beautiful\\"). Big time actors, but like most disaster movies, the big star here is the special effects. Very impressive. The cinematography and editing (which won Oscars) play a big part in the film as well. The only thing that can be considered negative about \\"The Towering Inferno\\" is the script. Like all of Irwin Allen's disaster films (as well as disaster films not produced by Allen), this one has its share of idiotic dialogue. Usually a movie that has this element bothers me like it did in the disaster films of the late '70s. But I didn't let that bother me with this film (same goes for \\"The Poseidon Adventure\\"). The action scenes and special effects are so spectacular, along with some good performances (particularly by Astaire and Jones), that it makes \\"The Towering Inferno\\" a great suspense thriller. <br />

B000EULJLU|3.0|What marked Tool's previous two releases is distinctly missing here...a quantum leap forward.  Aenima was so great that when Lateralus came out I didn't like it and put it away for over a year!  After I dusted it off and finally heard it for what it was it became my favorite Tool cd.  Parabola/Ticks & Leeches/Lateralus is the pinnacle of Tool's recording career. <br /> <br />10,000 days does not evoke that same response.  I agree with a previous poster that at times certain riffs seem reminiscent of Aenima and Lateralus.  Almost gone is the ultra-aggressiveness that once defined Undertow, connected Aenima, and highlighted Lateralus.  However, the aggression has been replaced with hypnotic auras rather than lyrical melodies.  Lateralus walked the fine line of aggression and melody perfectly.  10,000 days seems to meander more often than not.  Especially, during the long songs. <br /> <br />Hopefully, we won't have to wait another 5 years to spark up the discussion again.

B000ETQRCM|5.0|Before I begin, here's a thought, perhaps Grandma Pearl's jam is made from avocados. Just a thought... NOW, HERE WE GO... When I first heard this disc, I felt confused. The first four tracks are so ANGRY and INCENDIARY. What kind of music is this?! Where's the corporate-y, jangly, American Idol-y, ear candy rock we've all been subjected to the past few years?  <br /> <br />Then, I was like, whoa, the first four tracks are so REFRESHING, too. Like a punch to the face first thing in the morning! Where's the repetitve, brainless sludge of all those carbon-copy Creed-bands I hear on corporate radio? <br /> <br />Oh, wait, it's a new PEARL JAM album. Duh. OK, well, then, where's the uninspired, uneven mess I'd grown accustomed to since Binaural and (ugh) Riot Act? Well... It's gone. Blown up. UTTERLY DESTROYED. This album is IMMEDIATE, IN YOUR FACE and demands to be TURNED UP. (Actually, I've heard Eddie Vedder is a huge Sleater-Kinney fan (they've actually performed together) and I can hear S-K's influence here (S-K's last album, The Woods, is a similar in punch-to-your-face masterpiece). BUT, I digress...) <br /> <br />SO, as I settle in with my avocado, try to sort out this confusion, I realize. OH, wait a minute, this is ROCK and ROLL. This is that stuff I fell in love with back in my youth, the stuff like U2, REM, Led Zep, The Who, AC/DC, Neil Young... YES! That's what this is! ROCK AND ROLL! That's what \\"PEARL JAM\\" is! It's tasty licks, riffs, melodies and howling vocals. It's provocative lyrics that make me THINK. Wow! It's... it's freakin' rock and roll! It didn't die! I get it!  <br /> <br />NOW, just go buy this album, crank it up, enjoy something pure, instant and unmistakably powerful. This is why they make big speakers. The avocado album will proudly sit on your musical top shelf for the rest of your days. My favorite tracks? Well, they're all pretty good, but Unemployable is SOLID, Marker in  the Sand, Life Wasted, Comatose, Gone, Come Back, Inside Job, World Wide Suicide (what a ballsy title by the way), on and on, since when were there this many great tracks on ANY album?  <br /> <br />As far as comparisons go, I feel this is their most COMPLETE album. Sure, I loved Yield, No Code, Vitalogy, (the Bugs song was AWFUL though), VS. and OF COURSE! TEN (I really pity the folks that can't get beyond TEN). But, the avocado album is, from start to finish, A COMPLETE MASTERPIECE. The largest and most refreshingly \\"immediate\\" addition to PJ's vast catalog of great tunes. Pearl Jam's best album. Period. Eddie and the boys weren't lying when they said it. <br /> <br />From the opening assault of Life Wasted to the stunning, heart-breaking piano on Inside Job, dare I say, it's ONE OF THE GREATEST ROCK AND ROLL ALBUMS OF ALL TIME. Grammys all around. Thanks guys!

So far, I can't stop listening to this one and the more I listen, the more I want to keep listening. You'll still be amazed and the instrumental and lyrical quality. <br /> <br />The only complaint that I've seen and won't deny is that there is a little more filler than I like. Look at how Lance behaves like an animal at dinner. How Chef's request to talk to the plantation's chef is thrwn back in his face? There is some great camera work at the table: the family staying together (all the empty chairs signifying fatalities), the accordion player living in the past of Dien Bien Phu and the French political chit chat. Then of course there is the lady: strong drugs and string booze to bolster her up, and the strangely erotic bedroom scene. Although the French make many valid points, they too are a galaxy away from reality. The old guy saying we al have ot live together in peace (in hte middle of a major war), the others arguing over French poliitcs and the way they all dress up fro dinner, just like in the good old days. If all this is looked on as an extra, as a second movie, it is good.<br /><br />I also think Kilgore is also fleshed out nicely a little more, though this might be just increased familiarity with the movie. I also like Kurtz reading the news to Willard with all the kids looking on. It looks like Uncle Kurtz reading a fairy story. B000EULJLU|4.0|May 2nd saw the release of two great metal records, 10,000 days and Ministrys Rio Grande Blood.  Both records are quite different but are incredible releases nonetheless.  Ministrys is straight and to the point thrash metal and 10,000 days is more abstract and will probably take multiple listens to fully appreciate.  Im not sure how much I will like this one in comparison to my two favorites Aenimia and Lateralus but I'm by no means disappointed in this one.  There are some great songs such as Vicarious, The Pot, Rosetta Stoned, and Wings For Marie.  A lot of the other songs are slow instrumentals or a nurse and doctor talking about a patient in the background before the bizarre Rosetta Stoned starts.  If you're disappointed in this one maybe you should get Rio Grande Blood by Ministry.  It's instant gratification and just a plain fun record.  This Tool album will probably take awhile to digest.

B000EULJLU|5.0|To get the full extent of this album you MUST listen with an open mind, putting yourself in a distraction free sense. If you listen to this album with expectations for it to live up to other Tool CD's you probably will be disappointed. The music is thick and very well instremented. Everything is very harmonic and flows well together.  <br /> <br />My favorite song on the CD is \\"Right In Two\\" if you really listen to the words you will understand what Maynard is trying to get accross. It is almost an extension of Parabola. \\"Father why did you give these people free will, now they are all confused. Donkey's talk and monkey's know that Eden has enough to go around.\\" In my opinion I think this song is about pre-existance, peace with all existance, Spirits watching us through the veil \\"confused and amused\\" Then is goes on to show how humans progressed with free agency, given thumbs \\"to make clubs and beat each other down.\\"  <br /> <br />Rosetta Stoned does have guitar riffs that are very similar to other Tool works. I think Tool did that on purpose. I don't think they are having to rehash their old art. I think they are trying to tie their albums together to make a whole collective experience.  <br /> <br />Tool has grown and matured and if people can not see that or respect it then they aren't true music enthusiasts. You have to really appreciate music and the art of it to really get what Tool is trying to get across. If you aren't up to the challenge then don't buy the album. <br /> <br />The whole album does tell a story, every song does fit together you just have to listen with an open mind to get it. If you don't you never will. <br /> <br />And to all the haters out there:  I'd like to see you make an album that wasn't all sugar-pop and make it better than this.

B000006TRV|5.0|\\"The Wall\\" is a towering  Pink Floyd masterpiece from the brilliantly tormented mind of rock's literary genius, Roger Waters. David Gilmour takes somewhat of a supporting role here but he shines with his trademark vocals and unbeatable guitar. No one on earth plays like David Gilmour. Mason and Wright are further in the background but contribute their flavor as well.  <br /> <br />So much has been said already about \\"The Wall\\" that I won't take up the space to rehash the \\"plot\\". This amazing piece of composition is like an operatic, psychological rock journey through hope, despair, pain, alienation and once again a glimmer of hope. Although it is very personal it also becomes universal in its treatment of themes of the loss of childhood innocence, horrors of indoctrination into society, familial angst and the \\"numbing\\" of growing into adulthood and disillusionment. Everything about \\"The Wall\\" entitles it to be called a A Classic.

B000ETQRCM|5.0|I could write a review that encompasses the same old Pearl Jam review material, topics which drone on and on about wishful thinking in regards to Ten and Vs, and maybe even Vitalogy. I could also use the old standbys that pop up every few years when a new Pearl Jam CD is relased, like \\"Hey, it might be another Ten!\\" or other bloated hype. The problem is: what have Pearl Jam done wrong thus far? Nothing.     You see, Pearl Jam have done something admirable over the years, which can be seen as a stark rarity in the world of \\"what sells\\": They have made music on their terms. Not only have they done that, they have displayed their awareness of their percieved evils of fame, and what kind of creative hampering it can impose when a band like Pearl Jam is sitting on the underbelly of Ticketmaster and monsterous corporations. Along the way, hey, they have made some really great music at times, and these mentioned moments show a great band that knows it's place in the bigger spectrum of music. Pearl Jam never asked us to embrace everything they do; instead, they left it there for the taking. One has to respect that. I believe Pearl Jam's music is a reflection of where they are as artists, and change is inevitable in that sense. Change is natural as well, and brings about some of the most profound works, usually scattered through trial and error processes.    This brings me to \\"Pearl Jam\\", their eighth studio album. Once again, their newest release does not ride the coat tails of any other Pearl Jam offering. However, the basic tempo and texture of the album as a whole does indeed throw back to the early nineties, when flannel ruled the universe. Don't get me wrong, the sound itself does not make me think of \\"grunge\\" in the very general sense of the word. But what \\"Pearl Jam\\" has in common with it's early predecessors is quite noticable: it's about the individual songs.    What \\"Vitalogy\\" started was a string of CDs that were individually to be looked at as a whole. Each songon these CDs was part of a bigger overall texture. Not quite concept albums and definately not airtime singles compilations, their string of CDs in this time span never looked to be noticed. As said before, they were there for the taking.    This CD, however, is about the songs themselves, and the songs which Pearl Jam have graced us with this go-around are quite great at times. The hooks are there, but never in your face. With this easier accessibility, Pearl Jam have managed to do another great thing: they have created songs that don't come off cheesy or trendy. It's just Pearl Jam at it's best, and anyone who never had the patience to wait for them to come back to this template might want to see how they got here. It's a great collection of songs, though.    Standouts include \\"Severed Hand\\", \\"Unemployable\\", \\"Gone\\", and \\"Inside Job\\". I am not going to break the songs down and explain them, because there is nothing new or groundbreaking here. They are just great songs, which is a refreshing reminder that Pearl Jam can still make a CD which is built on the individual numbers. One would have to go back as far as \\"Vitalogy\\" to find this dynamic arrangement of songs.     Pearl Jam are \\"back\\" to some, but in reality, they never left. They have been creating what they want, and how they want all along.
B000EBEHR2|4.0|You don't need meds to like this album, although not as strong as the previous releases I still think this is a great album , especially a song to say goodbye is one of their best tracks ever. Again my thumbs up for this great band.

B0007OCG56|4.0|I just want to say that Tea Leoni has quickly become one of my favorite actresses.  She has shown in the past two or three years that she has talent I NEVER noticed before.  Anyways, I just wanted to make mention of that while it was on my mind.  Spanglish was a film I had wanted to see but never had the urge to spend money to see, but since the library had it and it was a free rental I picked it up over the weekend.  I just want to say that although it may have not been marketed perfectly, you have to know walking into this film that it is by no means a 'comedy' in the sense that most 'comedies' are today.  It's more along the lines of 'The Family Stone' just not as good.  It's a drama with funny scenes.  The heart of this movie is not to make you laugh but to make you think.  The story revolves around Flor Moreno (Paz Vega), a single Latina who is strugling to raise her pre-teen daughter Christina (Shelbie Bruce) in LA.  She gets a job house cleaning for the Clasky family, but she never could have known what she was getting herself or her daughter into.  The Clasky's are not your typical family...their off, just a little.  John (Adam Sandler) is a top-notch chef and the 'sane' one in the family.  Deborah (Leoni) is the high strung, depressed and over whelmed mother who doesn't know how to deal with herself let alone her family.  Deborah's mother (Cloris Leachman) is a drunk ex-jazz singer who serves as the reason and also the solution to most of Deborah's problems.  Bernice (Sarah Steele), the overweight daughter, is going through those normal teenage years and is starting to butt heads with her mother enough to loath her for it.  Oh yeah, and they have a son but he never speaks.  As Flor moves in with the Clasky's over the summer the families start to interact in ways neither of them expected and bonds are formed between each and evrey one of them, while walls are built around others.  Writer/director James L. Brooks for the most part gets this very right for hecreates people that we care about while painting a picture that is very believable.  The actors, especially Leoni, really sink their teeth into their roles, and Paz is such a warm hearted delight she's such a joy to watch on the screen.  Sandler tackled a role I would have never expected him too and he surprised me by pulling it off.  As I said, this is a dramedy with a lot of heart, a lot of humor and a lot of sincerity.  I'd pick it up, if you haven't already.
B000EULJLU|5.0|A much needed relief with all the poptrashed candy labeled overproduced crap thats out there ruining the music industry. A solid band does not have to crank out albums every 18 months and tour for only 6. A good album should hold a tour for 2 years... maybe 3 if the record sells world wide. That leaves a while to recover then go back into the studio for a year or 2. Look at all the good rock bands. They do not release a greatist hits album until 6 or more albums spanning over a decade. Your average commercialized band has a greatest hits after 3 albums. Its because they lack creativity. Those bands attempt and a poor one at that to give the fans what they want to hear not what they need to hear. Tool is one of those bands, a cerebral one at that creat music for sake of god music. The imagery and song writing convey many complex themes that force the listener to LISTEN and find the message that they need to hear. Come up with your own thought through the music. Don't criticise it. Listen to it. This album is meant to be played as one long thematic song. Like Lateralus, its an album that one can listen to without skipping around. Of you are looking for quick fixes, buy that processed crap out there. But if you want to sit back and truly understand and appreciate music for what it is, buy this album. Tool is a great rock band indeed and a monumental musical group over all. They don't need commercials, video, and reality TV to make them who they are. Tool will stand amongst the greats like pink floyd. Generations will buy tool albums for years to come. Enough said.
B000ETQRCM|5.0|I never thought Pearl Jam would write a song that could replace  Yellow Ledbetter  as their closing anthem, but they have.  If Pearl Jam played \\"Come Back\\" at the end of a show, I wouldn't be disappointed at all.  It has the same emotional outpour, a guitar part that can make you cry, and the overall feeling of closure.  Can you imagine the whole crowd singing along with Eddie during extended versions at the end of shows?  It would be a captivating experience that one would never forget.   <br /> <br />Pearl Jam have reflected on their career, taken aspects from every album (and the history of classic rock) and made them flow together in one deep, beautiful album.   <br /> <br />\\"Life Wasted\\" is the superior child of previous rockers like  \\"Brain of J\\" and \\"Blood.\\" After repeated listens, the chorus charges in your head with as much energy as anything Pearl Jam has done.  And just when the song slows down and seems to lose its fervor, McCready pulls out a guitar solo that's simply stunning.  It gives me goosebumps every time. <br /> <br />It's hard for me to be objective about \\"World Wide Suicide\\" since I played the song so many times before the album was released.  I don't think I can necessarily give a fair critique at this point.  I will say this though, \\"World Wide Suicide\\" has made the U.S. sing along with Pearl Jam again. <br /> <br />\\"Comatose\\" is immediate and raging.  Eddie's vocals are more raw than they have been in a long time.  This song is the twisted brother of \\"Spin the Black Circle\\" but it has got the advantage of being created now as opposed to 1994.  And what I mean by that is Pearl Jam is much more mature and aware of exactly what they're doing now than they were then.   <br /> <br />\\"Severed Hand's\\" chorus is an angled, descending wonder.  When the song slows down, Eddie unveils an awesome lyric, \\"If I don't lose control/ Explore and not explode...\\" with laser guitar effects shooting behind it that create this intense landscape in my mind.  I get the feeling of a battle that would take place in Star Wars. <br /> <br />\\"Marker in the Sand\\" has a breezy feeling reminiscent of Yield.  Eddie's vocals are once again jagged and sliding but they remain melodic as well, something that is rare and exciting.  And the chorus is probably the best on the CD, which is saying a lot because there are so many good ones.  Near the end of the song, there's a transition that reminds me of the feeling I got during some songs on Lost Dogs.  You know the one, Eddie even discussed in one of his recent interviews, when you imagine yourself driving (if you aren't) and passing open fields and clear skies. <br /> <br />\\"Parachutes\\" is really a mood piece.  It's like \\"Around the Bend\\" and \\"All Those Yesterdays\\" got married.  It has a nice sound and a lofty harmony that is very Beatle-like but is probably my least favorite song on the album.  It just doesn't capture me like the others do.  Then again, it wasn't meant to.  It's an easy, flowing song that just passes by.  There's nothing wrong with that. <br /> <br />I agree with the reviewer who said that \\"Unemployable\\" is a better REM song than REM has written in years.  It's so true.  I can picture Stipe and them doing this song and it works perfectly.  What really makes \\"Unemployable\\" succeed are the background vocals and the Neil Youngish plucks that are straight out of \\"Rockin' in the Free World.\\"  I think the song could've done without the \\"Ah Oh Oh\\" part, but it doesn't ruin anything. <br /> <br />\\"Big Wave\\" seems to be just a surfing song but really has deeper roots in evolution, \\"I used to be a crustacean/ In an underwater nation.\\"  The rhythm has a Riot Act feel to it but the solo's passion is right out of this album.  I don't think this song really adds much, but it doesn't take anything away from the CD. <br /> <br />\\"Gone\\" comes from a long tradition of songs like \\"Indifference,\\" \\"Immortality,\\" and \\"Given to Fly.\\"  It absolutely takes hold of the listener and puts them in the shoes of the character.  Everyone has those days when they just want to disappear from the world and this song captures the feeling perfectly.  My muscles relax as soon as I hear the beginning.  It belongs right up there with Pearl Jam's best stuff.  <br /> <br />\\"Wasted Reprise\\" is more than just filler.  It gives us a new perspective on the melody from Life Wasted that could easily get lost in the song's rush.  <br /> <br />\\"Army Reserve\\" is the best Binaural track that Binaural doesn't have.  At first you might not even pay attention to this song because there are so many great songs around it.  But after many listens, this track is outstanding.  And once again, the backing vocals are a huge part of it.  They harmonize with Ed's extending voice so well.  The guitars echo each other exceptionally throughout the song. <br /> <br />\\"Inside Job\\" is like a combination of \\"Space Oddity\\" and \\"Stairway to Heaven\\" done by Pearl Jam.  The piano reminds me of Van Halen at their best, but, of course, used for a much better song.  Eddie's whispering vocals and the eerie guitars create an incredible vibe that shimmers all the way through.  The progression is totally classic rock but works extremely well.  Towards the end, they take the song and make it their own.  This isn't Led Zeppelin or the Who, this is Pearl Jam and I wouldn't want it any other way.   <br /> <br />\\"Pearl Jam\\" A-

B000003CKH|5.0|I bought every Cake CD within the span of a few weeks after I finally got hooked by \\"Short Skirt, Long Jacket\\" from Comfort Eagle.  For a long time, Comfort Eagle was my favorite Cake album. Their first album suffers in quality, but considering they were unknowns at the time, one can't blame them for working on a shoestring budget.  The music is still great. <br /> <br />At the end of the day, I find myself coming back to Fashion Nugget again and again.  The big single on this album, \\"The Distance\\" is, in my opinion, one of the weaker songs.  That's saying a lot.  Check out Frank Sinatra, Friend is a Four Letter Word, and Daria for a small glimpse into the genius that is Cake.  The lyrical imagery and their catchy melodies quietly wrap themselves around your brain.  They are certainly the masters of making more out of less. <br /> <br />If you ever get a chance to go see Cake live, do it.  Watch everybody sing the lyrics to every song.  It's a great experience.  If you've heard their typical radio fare (Rock 'N Roll Lifestyle, The Distance, Never There, and Short Skirt) and have been even mildly interested, you owe it to yourself to go buy Fasion Nugget. 0451450523|5.0|Oh, for heaven's sake.  \\"Not as good as the movie?\\"  I want to hit my head against the wall.  Almost as brain-numbing as the same phrase applied to The Princess Bride.  If I weren't so dang verbal, I'd be speechless.  I will admit I have not been as engaged with Beagle's other stories.  But this book is one of a very few I've come across in my long history of reading-odd, moving, entertaining on the surface, but provoking in the most philosophical sense-lyrical, controlled, well-played, witty and haunting.  You don't get to write this kind of book often in your life.  In the play of the language there are shadings and suggestions of truth that could NEVER come out in a visual presentation of the \\"story.\\"  When you strip the plot of its verbal constructs, you lose the essential  joy, the possibility of discovery, the amazing chance to see a little more deeply into what your life may mean. <br /> <br />This story is romantic.  But in the most classic sense.  The unicorn's journey is away from a world that has grown too sure of its own reality, fascinated with the work of its own hands-blind, limited, short teathered and terrified of losing what it thinks it owns.  Beagle is right about us.  You could think he is talking about something as simple as growing up; certainly, growing up has hobbled my senses.  But stopping at that would be stopping short. <br /> <br />The sacrifice offered is archetypal, and I believe that is the source of the story's depth.  For this book is more parable than fable, and magic in a true way. <br /> <br />And there is this: why would the unicorn have made the journey, unless it was hope driving her?  And that, I think, is what I was left with when I finally finished the book.  I could feel hope.  And I could feel wonder.  This alone is worth the price of admission.  <br /> <br />But I make the book sound too serious and heavy.  The language flows beautifully.  The book is a joy to read.  Best to read it in springtime, though.  About the time the lilacs blow - <br />        <br />I've never met Mr. Beagle and probably never will.  But there is something about the writing in this book that makes me curious about what kind of person could have done it.  And that, I must say, is part of the pleasure-

B000EULJLU|5.0|THE BAND: Maynard James Keenan (vocals), Adam Jones (guitars), Danny Carey (drums & percussion), Justin Chancellor (bass).<br /><br />THE DISC: (2006) 11 songs clocking in at approximately 76 minutes. The case and contents are like no other compact disc I own... a book-like fold out with 30 pages of odd pictures (band pictures too) and 3-D lenses included (as part of the case itself). I feel a piece of velcro (or something) on the front cover would have greatly help to keep the whole package closed. The disc slides into the front inside pocket and is well protected (though hard to release). Recorded at O'Henry's, Grandmaster, and The Loft - all in Burbank or Hollywood, CA. Label - Sony Music.<br /><br />COMMENTS: I needed a few days to let this whole CD sink in. I can say that \\"10,000 Days\\" picks up where \\"Lateralus\\" left off. Dark, bleak, angst driven alternative meets heavy metal. Songs touch on death, love and love lost, inner pain and struggle, and even politics. Nothing surprising here. Seems like every 5 years we're treated to a new disc. \\"Undertow\\" (1991), \\"Aenima\\" (1996), \\"Lateralus\\" (2001), are all classic albums in their own right (not forgetting about their wonderful EP \\"Opiate\\" either). Sure, \\"10,000 Days\\" is more of the same - but TOOL is so vastly different than most anything else out there. Give this disc time and repeated spins to digest. Best rocking songs here are \\"The Pot\\", the opener \\"Vicarious\\", and \\"Jambi\\" with Jones' quick rhythm guitar licks. The title track and my favorite song on the album, \\"Roseta Stoned\\", both exceed the 11 minute mark. Both are trademark TOOL songs featuring soft intro's and a heavy middle section and incredible off beat Danny Carey drumming. This album also features a few soundscapes - little or no vocals and very mellow - \\"Wings For Marie\\", \\"Lost Keys\\", and \\"Intension\\". The only strike against \\"10,000 Days\\" is the odd closer, \\"Viginti Tres\\"... which sounds like an 5 minute exercise in scarce sound effects. Even if this album doesn't push the envelope, or take the band in a new direction - it's still great music by talented and accomplished musicians. Many reviewers are trashing this album saying it's \\"more of the same\\"... I see it as more of the same music I've loved for the past 15 years. It's just too bad we have to wait so long in between releases. Fans of Tool and Keenan's solo projects will not be disappointed here. Great disc.ush the envelope, or take the band in a new direction - it's still great music by talented and accomplished musicians. B000ETQRCM|4.0|There has been a lot of hype surrounding the new self titled Pearl Jam album as everyone says it is their best work in over a decade. Well that really says much since it can't be hard to be better than the bland rock they have been churning starting with the release of No Code. But with that said, this album is indeed better than anything they have released during that time frame, but still is no way near as good as their first three albums. <br /> <br />The album is the band's first in four years and the rest did do them good as there seems to be a spring back in their step, or it could also have been their time on the Vote for Change Tour lit a match underneath them, as sharing a stage with Bruce Springsteen can definitely have a positive effect on musicians. The album starts off with the twin guitar assault by Stone Gossard and Mike McCready on Life Wasted and the you should have downloaded it when it was free on the band's website World Wide Suicide which roar with ferocity that will undoubtedly will become a highlight of their live shows. Then Comotose is fast romp that is the closest the band has gotten to puck yet. <br /> <br />But what made Pearl Jam great is their diversity, yeah, they rocked, but were still able to slow things down, go acoustic, and make some eerily good music too. Marker in the Sand effortlessly switches from an angst fill verse to a mellower chorus with ease. The back to back Parachutes and Unemployable both sound like something from the British Invasion. The conclusion on Wasted Reprise sounds like something that could have come off their collaboration with Neil Young on Mirror Ball. The somber Come Back is their most heart wrenching song ever not named Betterman. Then the closer is the very moody Inside Job that builds to a eerie conclusion that grabs your attention for all of it's seven minutes. <br /> <br />The stories are more poignant as ever even as Eddie Vedder's delivery seems to be more indecipherable as ever. World Wide Suicide is a full on assault on the Bush administration. Unemployable follows a dude just issued his pink slip on his journey on trying to get another job. But the one that hits closest to home, and happens to be the closest to the Pearl Jam of old, is on Army Reserve, an elegy to the wives and children of those serving in our armed forces today. Hopefully this album singles an upswing the band will be on for years to come.
