B000EULJLU|5.0|The hiatus between albums was great but not necessarily void of progression. As we all know Maynard stayed busy with APC constantly honing his voice (whilst recovering from a wrecked larynx a la 'Ticks and Leeches') into a more sonorous acoustic instrument to convey his cynical other-worldly sense of humor. You can immediately hear this in the opening track 'vicarious', which can be taken as a keen jab at America's obsession with negative and gorey media. Move on to 'jambi', a well constructed song in almost every way, you get the best of Tools heavy guitar riffs and pounding drumming couresty Mr.C and you can surely hear Maynards growth and maturity at this point. 'wings for marie' is the first part of the infamous two-part serenade that began in lateralus, a powerful message about MJKs late mother. The albums namesake being the second portion. The ambient sentience of these songs combined should bring any true Tool appreciator to the brink of tears it's so moving. 'the pot' displays MJKs renewed vocals in all their glory, and his everpresent vitriol towards the ingnorant and self-proclaimed. 'lipan conjuring' is an tribal and other-worldly reprieve from modern music but is a welcome glue to the oncoming preternatural ' lost keys (blame hoffmann)'. 'rosetta stoned' follows its latter introduction brilliantly, bringing deeply desensitized accounts of a life changing abduction, in one's mind, and the inability to cope with the lack of evidence to persuade his doctor's of it's validity. Very humorous and moving again, typical MJK. 'intension' displays a distinct spiritual maturity which is only a precursor to the fully developed anthropomorphic 'right-in-two'. With a striking message to the bullheadedness of humankind, one can surely hear residual waves of 'emotive' on this track. 'viginti tres' leaves the album on that indinstict wordless path as tool has so often done. A mindblowing album.

6305320802|5.0|Bought this item in April 2006 and don't find the Todd-AO version as bad as described. It looks OK on a 32\\" non-HDTV screen but the degradation is noticeable when run on my computer's HDTV-like 19\\" screen. <br /> <br />The movie is timeless - accept it as Hollywood fluff, sit back and enjoy the outstanding dancing, rousing music that sometimes approaches the heroic, clever lyrics and actors in atypical roles. I wish they would show this in movie houses again as it cries out for big screen treatment. Until then, this two-set DVD will have to do, warts and all. <br /> <br />For the film buff it is worth the price just for the comparison between the two versions. The movie was shot twice to accommodate the different cameras.  Checking them out reveal subtle and not so subtle variations (the opening scene of \\"Kansas City\\" for instance) due to the angles and freshness of the actors and dancers (Todd-AO better in this respect, IMHO). There's also the scene in \\"Kansas City\\" where Will breaks through the packing case -- in CinemaScope he does it right, in Todd-AO only one foot breaks through and he is only kept from falling by Lizanne Truex's quick reaction. <br /> <br />I suggest that on your second viewing, concentrate on the two young girls who form an on-going sub-plot as teens infatuated with Will. They appear in every dance scene and almost attain co-star status yet are referred to only as \\"Dancers\\" in the credits. Pay particular attention to the pixie-like blonde, Lizanne Truex, who is emphasized throughout the film moreso than her partner, Jane Fischer. An outstanding and very talented actress/dancer who unfortunately didn't appear in any other films - a loss to the trade IMHO. She also had three one-liners, which is unusual for ensemble dancers. <br /> <br />Check out my profile's website for my tribute to her as well as the IMDb \\"Oklahoma\\" message board discussion titled \\"Who are the 2 dancers?\\" for recently discovered details about her. Recognition is long overdue.

B000ETQRCM|4.0|\\"Pearl Jam\\" shows off Pearl Jam as Eddie Vedder probably always wanted them to be--punky, political, ignored by the masses and embraced by the fans.<br /><br />It's a quirky album, dense and angry up front, mellower near the end. It's not their best album, so a lot of fans and critics will probably give it that backhanded compliment, the good old \\"Best album since...\\" qualifier. And, like all of their post-Vs. work, you have to listen to it a few times to get used to it. But it is worth getting used to.<br /><br />There are, by my count, three Pearl Jams. One produces gorgeous radio-friendly rock like \\"Black\\" and \\"In Hiding.\\" Another's responsible for all the pure angry discordant thrash like \\"Satan's Bed\\" and \\"Lukin.\\" The third frequently mars a perfectly fantastic album by throwing in a track or two of unlistenable junk. (Ever listen to \\"Bugs\\" and \\"Hey, Foxymophandlemama...\\" on \\"Vitalogy\\"? Me neither. I rest my case.)<br /><br />Call them the Good, the Bad and the Boring. Call them what you will, the success or failure of any Pearl Jam album depends on their being mixed in exactly the right proportions--a lot of Good, a little Bad, and almost no Boring.<br /><br />And I hate to say it, but there's just a little too much of the \\"Bad\\" Pearl Jam here for my taste. (There always needs to be some, or else things get a little vanilla, like on that Star Trek episode when Kirk got split into a \\"Good Kirk\\" and a \\"Bad Kirk\\" and the good one couldn't do anything. But I suspect Eddie puts in too much of the \\"Bad\\" on every album, just to throw fans and critics off the scent and avoid being pursued with the bloodhound-through-the-Georgia-swamp fervor of the early 90s.) On the plus side, though, there's almost no \\"Boring\\"--especially not in the first half.<br /><br />\\"Life Wasted\\" starts out pure anger and noise, and it's only mid-way through that it opens a little to let the Good in. As you can probably guess from the title, \\"World Wide Suicide\\" is another angry tune, with more than a little politics thrown in. (This is probably Pearl Jam's most political album yet, but I'm sure you've already decided whether to accept or ignore their politics, so it probably won't make a difference.) \\"Severed Hand\\"'s an angry, funky, propulsive little ditty about drug use; it's a great little tune, but by this point you'll be ready for a breather.<br /><br />Rest assured, the album calms down in the second half. It's as if Eddie decided to imitate Bob Dylan's electric/acoustic split on \\"Bringing it All Back Home\\" but instead ended up doing \\"electric\\" and \\"less electric.\\" \\"Parachutes\\", the first mellow tune, isn't up to the standards of, say, \\"Off He Goes\\" or their other better ballads, but at that point you'll be glad you're not getting an album full of \\"Satan's Bed\\" clones. There are a couple uptempo songs sprinkled in the back end, but by and large it's calmer sailing. In fact, it becomes a little...Springsteen-esque.<br /><br />That's right. Eddie Vedder's deep, dark secret is that he'd probably be perfectly happy as a slightly punkier version of The Boss. Like Springsteen, he fancies himself a working man's troubador; like Springsteen, he's really, at heart, a classic rocker. Eddie sang \\"Atlantic City\\" on one of his ealiest demos and often seems like he'd be comfortable in the Boss's career at any point besides the Born-in-the-USA stratosphere.<br /><br />Hence the anger and abrasiveness on this album. You may hanker for a return to the blissful days of early grunge, when all was still wrong with the world but at least all was right with music, when Pearl Jam ruled the airwaves. You may want that, but Eddie never did. And to avoid that stratosphere, he needs to be Bad, here and there.is probably Pearl Jam's most political album yet, but I'm sure you've already decided whether to accept or ignore their politics, so it probably won't make a difference.) \\"Severed Hand\\"'s an angry, funky, propulsive little ditty about drug use; it's a great little tune, but by this point you'll be ready for a breather.    Rest assured, the album calms down in the second half. It's as if Eddie decided to imitate Bob Dylan's electric/acoustic split on \\"Bringing it All Back Home\\" but instead ended up doing \\"electric\\" and \\"less electric.\\" \\"Parachutes\\", the first mellow tune, isn't up to the standards of, say, \\"Off He Goes\\" or their other better ballads, but at that point you'll be glad you're not getting an album full of \\"Satan's Bed\\" clones. There are a couple uptempo songs sprinkled in the back end, but by and large it's calmer sailing. In fact, it becomes a little...Springsteen-esque.    That's right. Eddie Vedder's deep, dark secret is that he'd probably be perfectly happy as a slightly punkier version of The Boss. Like Springsteen, he fancies himself a working man's troubador; like Springsteen, he's really, at heart, a classic rocker. Eddie sang \\"Atlantic City\\" on one of his ealiest demos and often seems like he'd be comfortable in the Boss's career at any point besides the Born-in-the-USA stratosphere.    Hence the anger and abrasiveness on this album. You may hanker for a return to the blissful days of early grunge, when all was still wrong with the world but at least all was right with music, when Pearl Jam ruled the airwaves. You may want that, but Eddie never did. And to avoid that stratosphere, he needs to be Bad, here and there.
B000060MMI|5.0|I deliberately seek out new music, and this band is probably more mainstream than most of what I listen to.  I don't listen to any particular genre, and in fact the main thing I'm looking for in a CD is a sound that is unfamiliar, like nothing I've heard before.  I make a habit of listening to one new cd a day at work (from the library) and this was one of the few keepers.  I don't understand the comparison to the Pogues and Dropkick, neither of which I heard before I came to Amazon to buy another FM CD.  To me, FM has a sound that is unique--at least on this CD, which is all I've heard so far.  My first thought was that it was a Celtic punk band--in other words, a novelty or a joke.  I still think it plays a bit like that, sort of like a musical experiment which the experimenters are having great fun with. <br /> <br />Anyway, I'm just writing this review because I'm not a fan, I'm not particularly drawn to this category of music, but this is still one of my favorite CDs.  This is one of the only CDs I listen to where I listen to every track, in order, and I enjoy every bit.  At first I thought all the songs sounded too much alike.  It's undeniable that there's not a lot of variance here, but even that grows on you; if you listen to it enough--and I have--you start to appreciate the subtle differences that exist among the tracks, and the even subtler transitions that occur from track to track. <br /> <br />To show my tastes in music, my favorites are:  any cd by Louis Prima with Sam Butera and Keely Smith; the Dirty Dozen Brass Band (best CD:  Buckjump); the Romanian Gypsy band Taraf de Haidouks (if you like Drunken Lullabies, check out Taraf de Haidouks, particularly their song Return of the Magic Horses, if you can find it online); the Stanford a capella group Talisman; and lots of other more obscure titles, and usually individual songs, not whole CDs. <br /> <br />Enjoy...
B0006399FS|5.0|U2 is one of the best bands in rock history because they are so passionate.  'How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb' is characteristic of what they can achieve when they channel their passion well.  This C.D. may become known as the pinnacle achievement of their later works.  It is consistent throughout, and, like 'All That You Can't Leave Behind,' they skillfully master their new evolutions of sound.  Still, it isn't as good as 'Achtung Baby' or 'The Joshua Tree,' but it so cohesive musically, that in some ways, it is more satisfying than any of their other albums.  And also like '...Can't Leave Behind,' they do leave behind the inconsistencies and meandering of 'Pop' and 'Zooropa'.      The album starts off full throttle with \\"Vertigo,\\" one of their best songs ever.  The passion is nearly answered later with beautiful and mesmerizing \\"City of Blinding Lights\\" and the musically muscular \\"All Because of You\\" (complete with a Bono scream that is nearly as transcendent as Roger Daltry from the Who).  Their passionate venue is extended with other fine songs: \\"Miracle Drug\\" and \\"Yahweh,\\" which has Bono singing tenderly and powerfully in alternate verses.  As propulsive and hypnotic as the recordings are, \\"Love and Peace or Else\\" provides a heavy dose of hard rock to give the C.D. more weight.    The album bursts with well-polished thrusts of sound, but it is framed by tender moments as well.  \\"Sometimes You Can't Make It on Your Own,\\" a personal song for Bono's deceased father, is a mournful elegy that still maintains a britzkrieg of sound.  Yet, \\"A Man and a Woman\\" is a necessary ballad with its intricate acoustic guitar and pensive lyrics.  The scope of the album is further enhanced with the playful song \\"Crumbs from Your Table\\" and \\"One Step Closer,\\" which borrows at least the mood from the Velvet Underground.    'How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb' showcases a skillfully crafted, powerfully delivered album that is channeled in a masterful way.  It all comes from an athleticdrummer, a brilliant guitarist, a motivated singer-songwriter, and a powerful bassist who simulates the group's throbbing heartbeat.  This album has all the serendipity of U2's best work.
B000E1ZBGS|1.0|The mini series was so much better. This try at Pride and Prejudice was a mistake from start to finish. The characters in this version of Jane Austen's book, except for Elizabeth and Darcy and Mrs. Bennet, are card board cutouts. Matthew MacFadyen seemed too soft to be Darcy. <br /> <br />The dance scenes at the hall in Meryton are much too long and took away time that the movie needed for character development. Too many extras took away the feeling that this was a country dance for the gentry, and not some crowded London ball. It made me feel that because so much money was spent on these scenes the producers wanted to get their money's worth in screen time. <br /> <br />Elizabeth's clothing was dark and dreadful. She looked like she was wearing what a servant would wear for most of her scenes. The Bennent home was shown as shabby. The Bennents had a good income they just spent it all as it came in so didn't save for the future of the Bennent daughters or Mrs Bennent. Because the estate was entailed on a male relative they would be turned out when Mr. Bennett died. That was Mrs. Bennet's biggest worry. Even then each daughter would get a small income. So why show them living like they were in such poverty? <br /> <br />Jane Austen was making a point about society, and how circumstances could change a woman's place in it. This version of Pride and Prejudice misses the mark here too. Jane Austen expanded on this theme with Sense and Sensibility. The 1995 movie version of Sense and Sensibility is also worth seeing. <br /> <br />This Pride and Prejudice was slow and tiresome, and I wondered how much longer? I had read good reviews and thought there must be something better ahead. The silly ending was all there was.  <br /> <br />Buy the A&E mini series instead, and don't forget to also buy the wonderful 1995 version of Sense and Sensibility with Emma Thompson and Kate Winslet. Both the 1996 TV and movie versions of Emma are also worth buying.

B000002AH1|3.0|I owned Live-Evil on Lp when I was younger and though this CD remaster is fabulous, it still sounds like a mish-mash of material.  I'm not crazy about the stuff recorded with the Brazilian chap, these little minature interludes between the tracks compiled and condensed from the Cellar Door sessions sound out of place and out of tune in places. Now that I've heard these a few times, I'm usually pressing the skip button to get to the next live track.  I'm not sure what Teo Macero was smoking (gimme some of that) but there are some HORRIBLE edits in the live material.  The feature review claims this is more focused that Bitches Brew.  That is sheer nonsense, this release is horribly disjointed due to those annoying little interludes with the Brazilian chap.  The tune selection is about as schizophrenic as it could get.<br /><br />On Nem Um Talvez, one of those little interludes, there is a point where it sounds as though Miles has been playing his horn slightly off mic and then suddenly turns and blasts this one note right in front of the mic. The singer is slightly out of key here making for an extremely uncomfortable moment for those who's ears can appreciate staying on the note!  From an engineering perspective, it sounds wretched and amature-ish to me.  Note to those who \\"love\\" this stuff:  This emporer was wearing no clothes at this particular moment.<br /><br />While I'm a big fan of McLaughlin's work with Miles, it doesn't do much for me here.  I'm thinking the band is probably better on the Cellar Door Sessions on the sides where McLaughlin is absent.  His playing doesn't sound particularly  thoughtful here, it sounds like he's just playing licks as fast as he possibly can. I hate to be irreverent since so may people love this release, but the guy sounds pretty sloppy (on this session)to me (I'm a life-long guitar player.  I'm no John McLaughlin but I know sloppy playing when I hear it).<br /><br />Gary Bartz and Miles's playing is amazing and I really mean that.  The improvisations are about as hot as it gets.  Jarrett, Henderson, and DeJohnette provide an incredible foundation to all that is going on here.<br /><br />Airto!  Mmmmmm.  Not so much. I get tired of Airto trying to whack, pull, bash, shake, and tinkle everything he can get his hands during every second the tape is rolling.  Dude.  It's ok NOT TO PLAY once in a while. His whistling during the opening track while Miles solos is just plain annoying.  He starts wailing like some Porteguese fisherman who has a big crab attached to his big toe by the claw that is chowing down on his foot.  \\"Waaaa la duh luh duh de laaaagggggghhhhhh!  Waaaaah duh luh luh du luh laaaaaaaagggggh!\\"  This occurs in a couple of the pieces, even smack dab in the middle of one of Mile's incredible solos.  He also has the annoying habit of shaking those  sleighbells of his while some of Jarrett's more intense improvisations are in progress.  It's very distracting.  He keeps shaking this thing that sounds like a box of Good-n-Plenty... Theatre size!  Much of what he plays sounds totally out of rhythmic context.  Some might find this energetic and exciting but I find myself wishing Airto would just STFU most of the time.  Contrast this to Airto's playing on the recently released \\"It's About That Time\\" Live at the Fillmore, March 7, 1970.  Airto isn't so intrusive on that recording.  I do like Airto's work with Santana and Weather Report.  I just find it obnoxious and annoying on Live-Evil.<br /><br />Jarrett's playing is amazing but I can't stand those nasaly little shrieks of joy he makes when he feels he's played something very cool. Surely they could have edited that stuff out. Really irritating.  He made an entire career out incredible playing accentuated by those nasaly, joyful shrieks of his.<br /><br />The artwork selected for this release (though painted by a white Swede who converted to Islam) is overtly rascist (turn it over) but then Miles always did have a problem with lumping all of us white folks into the same group of \\"white, blue-eyed devils\\".  I love Mile's music but this was a particular annoyance. Judgement coming from a man who fathered illegitmate children in all corners of the globe and all points in between is just ridiculous.<br /><br />Yeah, this review reads like I hate this disc but I don't.  This really is one hot band!  But there are some problems with the interludes and the inclusion of an unrestrained Airto.  I love Mile's music from this period.  I pull Live-Evil out and play it once in a while and enjoy large portions of it.  I pull out his other material such as Bitches Brew, Tribute to Jack Johnson, Big Fun and On the Corner far more frequenly.  As far as I'm concerned Live-Evil is for the complete-ist and I am a complete-ist.  Maybe the Cellar Door Sessions is better?  I don't know and I'm not going to spend $90.00 to find out.  Maybe I'll find a used copy on Ebay? :)<br /><br />Postscript:  I did manage to pickup a new copy of The Cellar Door Sessions without having to take out a second mortgage on my home.  It was work every penny of the $60.00 I paid for it.  If you like the live material on Live-Evil then you really want to get hold of a copy of The Cellar Door Sessions.  It puts all of the musicians in context, including Airto.  My criticism of him did not stand up when I heard the complete performances. The perception that he plays constantly is a product of the cruddy edits that Teo made to the performances to create this mess called Live-Evil.l of us white folks into the same group of \\"white, blue-eyed devils\\".  I love Mile's music but this was a particular annoyance. Judgement coming from a man who fathered illegitmate children in all corners of the globe and all points in between is just ridiculous.<br /><br />Yeah, this review reads like I hate this disc but I don't.  This really is one hot band!  But there are some problems with the interludes and the inclusion of an unrestrained Airto.  I love Mile's music from this period.  I pull Live-Evil out and play it once in a while and enjoy large portions of it.  I pull out his other material such as Bitches Brew, Tribute to Jack Johnson, Big Fun and On the Corner far more frequenly. 0316921173|5.0|This is an exhausting, stimulating, infuriating, and altogether remarkable book.  It is a story about addiction, to both traditional substances (e.g., alcohol, drugs) as well as some unexpected ones (e.g, tennis, information).  Wallace has imagined a very near-term future-one, in fact, that we're already living in since the novel was published in 1996-that is populated with more characters and plot lines than any writer should be allowed to put into three books combined.  Scattered amongst the 1,100 pages (including, by the way, about 100 pages of footnotes, which was a fictional first for me), the author does quite a bit of showing off; he is smarter than you and me and he seems to want us to know it.  However, those pages also contain some of the most hilarious scenes I have ever read and that is what ultimately redeemed the experience for me.  It is hard to recommend this book without reservation-how can anyone in good conscience compel you to surrender at least a month of your life, which is what it will take to absorb this magnum opus?-but I can say that it was thirty days well spent on my part.

B00005JOFQ|5.0|Although it's clear that BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN is terrific filmmaking, I was not really interested in seeing it until I heard Annie Prouix interviewed about the project. (It was her short story that the film is based on.) Prouix described how she had wrestled with finishing the tale for years, and had a much harder time with it than she had had with her longer works. (BTW, her book THE SHIPPING NEWS is a brilliant novel and a pretty good movie.)<br /><br />Anyway, Prouix did eventually finish the story, but had absolutely nothing to do with the filming of this movie. And here is the telling moment: Authors are almost always dissatisfied in some ways with the films of their work, particularly when they are not associated with the movie project as creative consultant or some such.<br /><br />Not Annie. She was absolutely floored that the movie had stayed so true to her story's original tone and purpose, and even substantially expanded upon it. (The fact the adapted screenplay won an Oscar for Larry McMurtry and Diane Ossana is a testament to its excellence.) What a story, and what a movie.<br /><br />INTERESTING SIDELIGHTS: BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN is a western set mostly in Wyoming and Texas. But it was written by a woman born in Connecticut, filmed in Alberta, and directed by a man from Taiwan. Go figure.

1592401791|5.0|I have read numerous books on the Beatles' story, the individual Beatles' biographies, and about their social lives after the shows ended. HERE, THERE, AND EVERYWHERE shines light on the Beatles' lives as recording artists in the studio, a topic usually untouched in most popular Beatles books. The story line is written with a direct nature that seems genuine because it doesn't seem to sugar coat their image or come accross as tell-all yellow journalism. No, it seems the author Geoffrey Emerick is calling each event as Recording Engineer for the Beatles as he actually saw them, and offers interestingly new points of view as to why the Beatles broke up, when the cracks started to appear in their relationships, and he also explains the immense pressure that everyone involved with the Beatles were under during their career.

B0002NRQTS|3.0|Presto marks the turning of another corner...a transition between Hold Your Fire and Counterparts. Fewer are the key driven riffs and the guitars begin to return. The melody is there still, but the new waveness has passed into a more laid back, mature piece of work. <br /> <br />I'll start on the weak end this time, and that's that there are about four songs on the record that are fine but nothing exceptional...and they all come in a row from Superconductor (chorus reminds me of Robert Palmer) through to Hand Over Fist. Any one of those songs could be cut and it wouldn't effect the album except make it leaner. Like all `bad' Rush songs, it seems, there are \\"moments\\" and \\"elements\\" that grab you...but on the whole leave you unimpressed. <br /> <br />Being one of the longer Rush albums, in terms of total tracks, it's encouraging that you're left with what I consider seven pretty darn good songs (hey - more than an entire album's worth in 1978..!). Available Light and Scars mark the two unheralded gems. The former has a great dynamic and melody to it...and a lilting part of the chorus that mentions the title that I really like. It's a good reach for Geddy. Scars smacks of Grace Under Pressure with its bobbing, snappy bass line, crystal keyboard accents, and tribal beat. GREAT song.  <br /> <br />Chain Lightning and War Paint each fall into the oft-overlooked category as well. Lighting has a great set of lyrics and a catchy chorus (respond...vibrate...feedback...resonate). Nice tempo changes too. A nice bass line and crystalline keyboard riff drives the verse.  <br /> <br />The title track, Presto, is amongst my favorites too and one of the rare Rush titles that qualifies as a ballad. I would love to hear this done with Alex acoustically at the front of the stage. This would be great to hear live. More strong lyrics again (man, we seem a million miles away from By-Tor right now....and that's quite the good thing).  <br /> <br />This takes us to the most prominent and clearly strongest songs on the record. Show Don't Tell is a driving little number that kicks the album off with intensity and purpose. Love the guitars here. Just a great song all the way around. Nice band dynamic here...playful, riffy, catchy, etc. Finally The Pass is a wonderful tune (probably a top five Rush song for me). I loved it long before I learned the band did too, but was happy to hear that tidbit just the same. One of the most well-crafted songs the band has ever done. There's a great dramatic tension built from verse to chorus and then into this strong break before the tempo drops back down into the verse format again. Excellent. <br /> <br />Generally Presto is a pretty laid back record, but not in a way we've seen before. Rather than subbing guitars for keyboards and teching it up, it's more an exercise in going to a cerebral and melodic place. It's a more mature place this Rush album takes us to, both lyrically and tonally. And I like it quite well. <br /> <br />I'm knocking it a star-and-a-half for filler and excess. This is a very good 11 song disc that's clearly a notch above Power Windows and Hold Your Fire, but it would be an extraordinary (and 4-star) 8-song event with the correct selections. <br />
B000000WJK|5.0|Sheer bliss, a record full of wonder with Nick McCabe's hypnotic, soothing guitars as it's focal point. Richard Ashcroft's vocals accompany rather than lead through this ten track psychedelic voyage.<br /><br />A different beast altogether from the worldwide smash 'Urban Hymns' but if you liked that album's dreamier songs such as 'Catching The Butterfly' or 'Neon Wilderness' then 'A Storm In Heaven' is definitely worth checking out.<br /><br />There are five songs that make this album essential and in my opinion they are 'Star Sail', 'Slide Away', 'Beautiful Mind', 'Make It 'Til Monday' and 'See You In The Next One (Have A Good Time)'. They are all spellbinding, goose-bump inducing jams that (to use a Richard Ashcroft song title!) break the night with colour. Listen to any of these tracks on headphones while on a late evening stroll by the riverside or through a forest or across a wide open field and they capture your imagination.<br /><br />'Beautiful Mind' is the best of the bunch and is a contender for my all time favourite song! It's a majestic masterpiece that I adore wholeheartedly, every note is perfect and every second is awe-inspiring to me. Listen to it at an ideal time in an ideal setting and hopefully it will grab you in the same way.<br /><br />'A Storm In Heaven' is a much-treasured album in my collection.

From the voyeuristic habit we all have in seeing someone else reach the end, to Maynard's description of his mother's journey through that path, to the fatal consequence of setting people against each other in a war environment, the album delivers in giving the listener different perspectives on this subject matter. B000EULJLU|4.0|Here's where I'm coming from:  I first learned of Tool back in the early 90's when Sober and Prison Sex were being aired on MTV.  They stood out, for obvious reasons.  I thought they were a tight band that could rock, but I didn't pick up the album at the time.  Then Aenima came out in 97.  Again, the videos intrigued me, but not enough to pick up the album.  Then then singles wouldn't stop coming.  When finally the SIXTH single off the album (insane right?) was being played for the first time on the radio, I told myself, \\"I gotta get this album.\\"  This band had to be taken seriously not only as a metal band, but as an artist.  Needless to say, I was completely blown away by Aenima.  It was one of the few albums I've ever purchase where I was entranced by the filler material.  I returned to the record store and purchased Undertow shortly thereafter. <br /> <br />The four years that followed caused to forget about Tool a bit.   <br /> <br />Then I started hearing rumors about Lateralus and I was immediately excited.  I was literally counting down the days until its release.  As many of you, I purchased it the first day and listened to it on the ride home from the record store.  It took me about four of five listens to \\"get\\" Lateralus.  It seemed very slow and boring the first time and gradually hooked me in with each subsequent listen.  Once I was completely on board, I began to dissect the lyrics, the artwork, the meaning, and hear the album as one body of work and not individual songs.  I also reexamined the videos and purchased Salival.  <br /> <br />When I stepped back for a moment, I realized that I was completely obsessed with this band.  The climax on Laterlus (track 9) was shaking me to the bone. <br /> <br />Then another four years passed. <br />  <br />Now the review: <br /> <br />My first listen is usually a sampling:  I bounce from track to track listening to each of them.  My second was more thorough (in the car), the third was with headphones, and the fourth was again in the car (this time while drinking tea). <br /> <br />There are some good tracks on this album.  Vicarious, Jambi, and The Pot are clearly the most accessible tunes.  To me, they fall somewhere in between Undertow and Aenima and Tool fans should be pleased with them. <br /> <br />Te remaining songs are what have become so controversial, particularly the 17-minute \\"Wings\\" ode to Maynard's mother.  And I do agree with many of the criticisms.  But I think the problem isn't a \\"creative\\" one, but one of indulgence.  The key element in pulling off a prog-rock album is pacing, and this album has some difficulty moving on in certain points. <br /> <br />If I were to edit the album, I would axe track 3 (Wings for Marie) altogether and cut off track 4 at the eight-minute mark.  Rosetta Stoned is similarly overly indulgent.  I would cut that track off shortly after it climaxes (it goes on for three more minutes).   <br /> <br />Doing this cuts about 10-15 minutes off the album and would have made it flow from one track to the next effortlessly without trashing key points in the album. <br /> <br />Other than the pacing (and maybe the ordering of the tracks), the songs are wonderful in their own right.  Track 4 (10000 days) starts out very slowly and develops into this really great, rhythmic bassline, almost out of nowhere.  Track 7 (Lost Keys) is totally haunting.  Track 8 (Rosetta Stoned), at least the first eight minutes, is Tool at its very best.  And Track 10 (Right in Two) is an epic masterpiece not unlike many of the tracks on Aenima. <br /> <br />I agree with one of the commetors below that you should try to listen to it with headphones.  Maynard's voice comes in much better and leads you through this jungle.

You must learn proper viewing technique.  I bet you're like me and put the glasses right up to your eyes as if they were glasses.  How else can you explain these 1 or 2 star reviews?  All I saw was two blurry photos when I did this.  It wasn't until the next day that I discovered that you have to take your eyes away from the glasses and look through them from a few inches away. 0790731002|4.0|Batman Forever is often credited as the beginning of the decline in the Batman film series. If I was a bettin' man, I'd say this isn't because it's slow, uninteresting, or void of style, rather because of its lighter approach. With the first two Burton Batman films (Batman, Batman Returns), the atmosphere was delightfully dark. Not to mention the colorful and equally menacing villains. Batman Forever still has that effect, but doesn't drench every scene with the serious, gothic mood that some of the comics and animated series have come to be known for. This makes the movie a bit more child-friendly and leaves out any extra tension to make room for some good old fashioned superhero fun. And what's wrong with that?<br /><br />I hadn't seen Batman Forever in...well, forever. It had been a while, and I was afraid that with my expanded view of cinema as well as Batman that I would find it cheesy and boring. I was pleasantly surprised. I realized why I had enjoyed it so much to begin with. It's an action-packed adventure that never let's up on the thrills. Except for a few scenes that detail the relationship between Batman/Bruce Wayne's new love interest and a few scenes that expand on the story of Dick Grayson/Robin, I found that most of the movie was bursting at the seams with awesome hand-to-hand combat sequences and litterally explosive special effects.<br /><br />One of the best parts of Batman Forever is Tommy Lee Jones and Jim Carey as the leading villains. Tommy Lee Jones plays TwoFace -- the ex-lawyer who after a freak accident on the job burned half of his face into a horrific mess, resulting in psychological trauma severe enough to split his personality right in two, hotwiring his mind for fiendish criminality. Jim Carey plays The Riddler -- an almost genius inventor that after being turned down by his once idolized Bruce Wayne because his quirky mind-reading invention would raise \\"too many questions\\", shifts into a clever criminal that taunts Bats with riddles and subliminal clues. Jones was absolutely maniacal as TwoFace. From his throaty chuckles to his frantic fits of rage, he fit perfectly into the role. So what if it was way off from the comic book takes on the character? It was too crazily cartoonish not to love! Jim Carey -- goofy and comically intriguing as always -- really gave spice to the character of The Riddler with whacky antics and over-the-top manic traits (who can watch that Batcave scene and tell me it's not one of the most amusing scenes in Bat-history?). While Val Kilmer and Chris O'Donell did fine as the heros, the show was undeniably stolen by the hands of these two brilliant actors that really made each scene worth while.<br /><br />In conclusion, I think that while Batman Forever fails to live up to its predecessors, it makes up for it in an exciting and at times campy approach that causes it to teeter on the line between child-friendly fun-fest and adult-friendly punch-n-kick-fest with grace. From the engaging story to the wild performances to the amazingly well-fit score, it ain't no rocket science why this one's a keeper. The key to enjoying Batman Forever is to swallow your comic book ego and simply have a good time. There's plenty of memorable lines and stylish fights to keep you coming back for more, and if you're willing to go up a bit in price, the Special Edition Two-Disc DVD -- loaded with extras -- really adds to the experience.clues. Jones was absolutely maniacal as TwoFace. From his throaty chuckles to his frantic fits of rage, he fit perfectly into the role. So what if it was way off from the comic book takes on the character? It was too crazily cartoonish not to love! Jim Carey -- goofy and comically intriguing as always -- really gave spice to the character of The Riddler with whacky antics and over-the-top manic traits (who can watch that Batcave scene and tell me it's not one of the most amusing scenes in Bat-history?). While Val Kilmer and Chris O'Donell did fine as the heros, the show was undeniably stolen by the hands of these two brilliant actors that really made each scene worth while.    In conclusion, I think that while Batman Forever fails to live up to its predecessors, it makes up for it in an exciting and at times campy approach that causes it to teeter on the line between child-friendly fun-fest and adult-friendly punch-n-kick-fest with grace. From the engaging story to the wild performances to the amazingly well-fit score, it ain't no rocket science why this one's a keeper. The key to enjoying Batman Forever is to swallow your comic book ego and simply have a good time. There's plenty of memorable lines and stylish fights to keep you coming back for more, and if you're willing to go up a bit in price, the Special Edition Two-Disc DVD -- loaded with extras -- really adds to the experience.

B000E97Y6K|1.0|I guess I'm kind of picky: I like movies that are entertaining. This one has so many faults that I was relieved when it ended. One of those faults is that it took over three hours to end this abomination of a movie. I'll just list out some of the other problems with this movie:    1. Editing - Every scene in a movie should contribute something to the plot or character development. Too many scenes in King Kong were just there as gratuitous action without adding anything to the plot or characters. And the viewer's response is, \\"Here we go again, the characters are going to fight mudpeople, dinosaurs, bugs, Kong, etc....\\" Peter Jackson really needed a strong-minded editor to edit out about half of this movie. Then the editor should have burned whatever was left.  2. Poor special effects - In this age of amazing CGI effects, there is no excuse for unbelievable visuals in a movie, especially one with a large budget and a well-known director. The effects in King Kong are so bad that you can see the outline of the actors against the greenscreen. It makes it really hard to watch an action scene when the viewer can see a visual difference between the actors and the effects. One might expect them to integrate the effects better with the actors.  3. Poorly thought out action scenes - One of the scenes with the bad CGI/Actor integration issues involved the characters running through a brontosaurus stampede. Those Brontosauri were practically stepping on the actors, yet no one got so much as a little bruise from the experience. They should have been squashed like bugs. Although, that might be wishful thinking. In another scene, Kong is fighting off several T-Rexes while carrying Ann Darrow, the female lead character, in his hands like a Barbie Doll. The scene goes on and on, with Kong tossing Darrow from hand to hand while he's swatting the T-Rexes, and then running, ape-style, with his knuckles often hitting the ground for balance and traction. If Darrow were really in his handwhen it hit the ground, she would have been completely crushed. But, at the end of this drawn-out fight scene, her dress wasn't even torn. Granted, this is a sci-fi/fantasy movie, but one would expect some of the physical laws of the universe to hold true.  4. Continuity issues - First there were the mudpeople, whose tribe suddenly dropped off the face of the planet about mid-way through the movie. Did the director forget about them, as if they were some kind of disposable plot device, useful only so long as they presented an obstacle to the main characters? And then there's the issue of transporting Kong. By the time the explorers/film-makers got to Skull Island, their boat had taken such a beating that it was barely floating. And the boat appeared to be smaller than King Kong. Peter Jackson expects us to believe that these resourseful folks somehow managed to get the oversized ape onto this too-small boat. And, how did they get him from the shore to the boat? All they had was one small dinghy that was barely big enough for the landing party. Then, we are to believe that this non-seaworthy boat got the big ape back to New York. Hmmm... no wonder the director chose not to include the boat-ride home in this movie. That's the one scene he managed to edit out of King Kong.    Don't bother seeing thim movie unless you're interested in how bad a big-budget movie can be.
0887307280|5.0|Michael Gerber believes that the reason most businesses fail is because they are started by people that have skill in creating a product, not in running a business. This lack of business savvy causes the majority of startups to fail.  <br /> <br />To avoid this, Gerber tells his readers to work on their business, not in it. He recommends developing a business model that relies on a pre-defined way of doing business, rather than one that depends on your employees. This way, you can ensure consistent excellence from your company without overseeing day-to-day operations.  <br /> <br />The E-myth by Michael Gerber is full of practical advice for operating your small business successfully. I would highly recommend every entrepreneur read this book and apply the principles it contains.

B0000549B0|5.0|During the past decade, Hollywood has shown a strong tendency to do movie remakes. Additionally, plans are in the works for many more remakes in the near future. A few of these remakes are either just as good as the original or in rare cases even better than the original. Most remakes are worse than the original and are all too often just plain awful in their own right. <br /> <br />There are some movies that are just about perfect in their original form and as such should never, ever be subjected to the remaking process. One such flick is the 1950 classic Harvey starring James Stewart as Elwood P. Dowd. As to who plays the title role, that is a good question.  <br /> <br />You see, title role is played, at least according to Elwood P. Dowd, by a six foot eight inches tall rabbit named Harvey who is invisible to everyone except Dowd. Dowd is a barroom regular who drinks with Harvey every day and opens doors for his rabbit friend who Dowd refers to as being a \\"pooka.\\" Only problem is that Dowd is the only person who has ever seen Harvey.  <br /> <br />Dowd's relationship with Harvey is most embarrassing for the other members of his family who think that he has flipped his lid. Chief among these relatives is Dowd's sister Veta Louise Simmons (Josephine Hull) who has been assiduosly trying to get her beloved daughter Myrtle Mae Simmons (Victoria Horne) married off. Everytime Dowd talks to Harvey in the presence of a suitor to Myrtle Mae has the effect of scaring off the suitor who thinks that the family is nuts. The same goes for whenever Veta Louise Simmons has a tea party for other older age ladies. This is especially important since these parties are meant to introduce Myrtle Mae Simmons to the mothers and aunts of prospective suitors with the idea being that if the society matrons approve of her, they will talk to their sons and/or nephews about the idea of getting married to the younger Simmons female.  <br /> <br />After a party in which Veta Louise Simmons triedto introduce her daughter to prospective suitors went up in smoke after Elwood P. Dowd showed up and brought Harvey with him and introduced Harvey to the guests, Veta Louise decides that she has had enough. She goes to Dr. Chumley's Rest Sanatorioum and endeavors to have Elwood committed there. However, due to her behavior when she gets flustered and a mixup on the part of the staff, Veta winds up getting committed herself! Eventually, things get sorted out and then Dr. Chumley decides to go after Elwood himself.  <br /> <br />Harvey is a movie masterpiece of the first order. It is well done in just about every respect. It is also a model family movie outside of Elwood's tendency to drink at bars and the fact that there is some unnecessary violence. Harvey contains plenty of slapstick and screwball humor however, unlike most movies of the type, it is very well thought out. If you want a movie for the whole family, then Harvey is a movie well worth considering.  <br />

B00005JOWR|4.0|Thank You For Smoking is a clever story that delves into what righteous morality can turn into if continually reasoned through a filter of moral subjectivity; as well as how reasoning is not always the greatest tool for the argument of right and wrong- but always seems to win the fight regardless.<br /><br />Nick Naylor is a lobbyist for Big Tobacco, he is not only the main character but the hero of this story.  He's quick to the draw and seemingly unbeatable.  He fits the bill as a fighter for justice and the defender of the helpless; we may dislike what the justice is or who the helpless are though.<br /><br />The supporting characters, among many, include his son, fellow lobbyists (alcohol/firearms), a tricky journalist, and a righteous Vermont congressman; all mesh well playing into the Naylor's plot as cartoon characters gravitating so easily into his super human will without much resistance or strength.  There are times when Naylor may seem out of his league or even beaten, but like any superhero he always seems to magically overcome those times without any reasonable answer for why or how it happened.<br />The greatest strength of the movie is the sharp comedic acting of the great cast and clever dialogue move the story to it's climatic final scene of victory.<br /><br />This movie is not far removed from a graphic novel or comic book story: the humor is absurd, the characters are flimsy, and the storyline is choppy, but the truth is found in these ridiculous weaknesses and the overall irony of it all.

B000E97HIA|4.0|Returning from his own self-imposed indie music wilderness exile in 2004 with \\"Musicology\\", Prince offers \\"3121\\".  This record seems to be a bit more, I don't know, sexy or fun come to mind.  It seems that Prince made his textbook record with \\"Musicology\\", here he just wants to get down.<br /><br />Some of my favorite cuts are, but aren't limited to: the title track, a deep, hypnotic, funk number, one that resurrects the vocal character Camille from the dead. \\"Lolita\\" is a fizzy, pop number that recalls some of his more pop oriented material. \\"Te Amo Corazon\\" the first single, may've seemed leaden at first listen, but amongst the other programmed work, it actually provides a lush organic breathing space. It truly sounds prettier upon each listen.  \\"Black Sweat\\" draws a falsetto vocal reminiscent of \\"Kiss\\", but an updated hip hop dance element that characterized his \\"Symbol\\" album in 1992. Ironically, he almost comes close to making this the dirtiest cut on the record.<br /><br />Lyrically, it is the same material Prince has always written about, love & sex. Though, for his age love is more the subject on the platter today. His efforts to bring his faith (as a Jehovah's Witness) on \\"The Word\\" sort of just float there.  Musically, though, this is a fun cut.  It could've been pulled from 2001's \\"The Rainbow Children\\" which dealt with similar subject matter.<br /><br />Overall, Prince makes another fun, if tame record that shows that while he may not be the innovator he once was, he sure is better than the slew of those who copied him in his wake.

The mystery is one of her earlier ones and is a classic dead body in a room story. Poirot works with Dr. Sheppard, from whose point of view the story is told, to interview all the suspects and at the end puts everything together in a way that leaves us hitting ourselves over the head for not having seen what was right in front of our eyes. <br /> <br />There are those who have argued that Christie cheated on the ending, which has a true surprise twist, but I think that her ending is one of the most brilliant plot devices ever used. B0007Y08QA|5.0|Many movies take us into existentialist nightmares, though most are not this stylish.  You know the drill - lots of black, white, gray and blue, steel, concrete, chrome, and glass, no natural materials, no warmth, no light, only the suffering protagonist.<br /><br />The Machinist falls neatly into this category, but unlike so many of them, it has a point, it is going somewhere, there is an \\"aha\\" moment that makes sense of this descent into hell.  That's worth knowing because the world you enter is dark indeed.  Trevor, the Machinist, cannot sleep, and it is killing him.  As has been reported elsewhere, Christian Bale shed 63 pounds to play this part, 63 pounds he didn't have to spare.  He looks cadaverous, haunted.<br /><br />As we are drawn into his private and desperate existence we wonder, as he does, if he is really losing his mind completely or just having a terribly difficult time.  Both Jennifer Jason Leigh and Aitana Sanchez-Gijon are wonderful, offering tantalizing glimmers of hope.  Part of the intrigue of this movie is that we experience Trevor's struggles as he does, and we begin to suspect some undercurrent just as he does, our level our understanding never gets ahead of his.  We wonder, as he does, if he is the victim of some truly devious conspiracy, there seems to be so much evidence.<br /><br />Then we wonder, as he does, if the truth might be something less spectacular, but far more chilling, much closer to home.  Trevor's world is so extreme, and so relentlessly painful, that it can only be explained by something ghastly, something unthinkable.  It is.  There is nothing funny or warm to be found here, but The Machinist is a brilliant film featuring an astounding performance by Christian Bale.  If you're not afraid of the dark, you will find it riveting.

B000EULJLU|5.0|It should come as no surprise that Tool's latest release is met with a fair share of criticism.  Five years to sit and contenplate a group's coming release is a long, no, a dangerous amount of time.  With new material on the way, fans and followers were literally salvating over the release of \\"10,000 Days.\\" <br />What one must understand before opening the elaborate packaging to this album is that, this is not music in a traditional sense.  Tool's sound has been a constantly evolving animal; one that can only be viewed in snapshots of time.  From the beginings of Tool to this newest release, Tool has mastered packaging a true experience into an 80 minute disc.   <br />On \\"10,000 Days,\\" dark soundscapes and the deepest of tribal grooves take the listener on a journey, much like Pink Floyd's \\"Dark Side of the Moon\\" (both figuratively and literally).  A closed mind will not even begin to understand what Tool tries to accomplish here.  Only the patient will see... <br />Once Tool's sound solidified with the release of Aenima, listeners soon realized that Tool was not a band to easily give up accessibility.  In fact, the inaccessability of Tool's music has increased with each album.  \\"10,000 Days\\" takes this to an extreme.  This album takes work on the part of the listener.  Not a little work, a LOT of work.  One must be dedicated and disciplined in order to see the forest for the trees, but, that being said, the rewards are huge.  Tool as given listeners a gift that will continue to give long after many current releases have been all but forgotten.   <br />Since the band's second major release, the image of a 'third eye' has accompanied the albums in some way, both in the artwork and in the lyrics.  In this particular case, the eye physically appears on the disc in a spriral design.  This is not just artwork.  This is a message.  A clue or key to understanding.  In order to see, you must open your eyes.  In Tool's case, you must open your third eye...your MIND.   <br />Is this album a masterpiece?  Time will tell. <br /> <br />As a greedy fan, I can't wait for the next release, but I'll wait as long as I have to.
B0007Z4S4C|5.0|At last after twelve studio albums (including two special collectors editions for fan club members only) since the break up of the world's greatest rock `n' roll band, Led Zeppelin, after the tragic death of drummer John Bonham, Robert Plant has released an album that stands up to the work of his illustrious previous band. The Mighty Rearranger is a mighty album which should be included in any record collection of people that like serious rock.<br /><br />There are many mitigating circumstances why Robert Plant has made such a successful return to the scene. Firstly, on this collection of works Robert Plant has not been afraid to admit his history, and influences. I am not for a moment suggesting that he has gone out and tried to create an album that sounds like a new Led Zeppelin album, but on the other hand he has not allowed them to stand in the way either. Quite naturally Robert Plant was the lead singer and one of the main songwriters within Led Zeppelin, so of course there are moments which are very Zepplenish, but so what? There are also many other influences on the album: Robert Plant's fanaticism with Moroccan music is heard, with a lot of use of modern technology to give each song a very up to date sheen. There is of course a lot of purely original Robert Plant in there to.<br /><br />But most importantly, although this album will be known as the new Robert Plant CD, it's actually credited to Robert Plant and The Strange Sensation, and the boys in the band have made no small contribution to the album.<br /><br />After the demise of Robert Plant's previous band `Priory Of Brion' in 2001, he wasted no time getting a new band together calling them `Strange Sensation'. Now the nucleus of the band has been together for over four years, and they are as tight as the All Blacks back row. Little idea was given of how successful a union this was going to be when they released their first album together, the quite frankly appalling `Dreamland' (2002), a collection of hurriedly put together cover versions that lacked any soul or direction.<br /><br />But after almost two hundred concerts as a band this has already been put behind them. All twelve songs on the album are originals, with thankfully not a cover version in sight. The writing, conceiving and creating of each song is credited equally amongst the band; so is the mixing, recording and producing. So for the first time since his Zeppelin days Robert Plant finds himself in more of a band situation, and if this is the result long may it continue. Not one note is wasted here. The dual guitars of Skin Tyson and Justin Adams weave in and out of each song providing the necessary textures.<br /><br />For those of you missing the old rock `n' roll thunder of the Zeppelin days you will not be disappointed by the bluster of `Tin Pan Valley' or the title track. In fact any song on this collection could have fit into the Led Zeppelin catalogue.<br /><br />Clive Deamer has the impossible job of no matter how much time has past, John Bonham left huge footprints to follow in when you are drumming for an ex-Zeppelin man, but instead of avoiding the issue this very talented skinsman meets the problem head on. If a song requires some percussion that resembles the style of the great man, then that is what the song gets. There is no use being coy about it, the job has to be done, and I'm sure the great man himself would have approved of the job done here by Clive Dreamer. Although, of course, for most of the time he just sounds like the very good musician that he is.<br /><br />John Baggott plays all the keyboards and is the man probably the most responsible for giving this album it's cohesion, setting up a wall of intricate keyboards and allowing the guitars and Robert Plant's vocals to sparkle over the top.<br /><br />The find of the album, though, is the bass playing abilities of a certain Billy Fuller, who is such a unique bass player that I would go as far as to say he has created a completely new way of playing the four string. His work can be heard all the way through the album, but is at it's most prominent best during second song, and first single off the album, `Shine It All Around' where he achieves a bass sound that can only be described as filthy. He is even allowed enough space for a short solo.<br /><br />Unfortunately, due to all musicians having such tight schedules these days, well the good ones anyway, since the recording of this album there have been two changes to the Strange Sensations line up: Billy Fuller moving on up the rock `n' roll family tree to be replaced by Robert Plant's old cohort Charlie Jones, and Skin Tyson being replaced by Porl Thompson, who had played with Page and Plant on their reunion tour. It's a pretty fair swap in both cases I feel.<br /><br />This must not of course take the focus of attention away from the main man himself, Mr Robert Plant, aka Percy to his friends (a reference to his affection for gardening and Percy Thrower, the man behind the gardening programmes on the British Broadcasting Television network. Led Zeppelin's gardening exploits whilst on the road are nearly as well documented as their music). Robert Plant is now in his sixth decade, and although he can still belt out a rocker with the best of them, he uses the new maturity in his voice, that only comes with the accumulation of years, to full effect. He's not kidding when on `Shine It All Around' he sings \\"These are the best days of my life/Bright, strong and golden', or perhaps more tellingly on `Tin Pan Valley,' showing his new re-found confidence and comfort with the past. \\"I come from Tin Pan Valley, and I'm moving right along/I live in a former glory, so long ago and gone/I'm turning down the talk shows, the humour and the couch /I'm moving onto higher ground, I've found a new way out.\\"<br /><br />Mighty Rearranger brings out all the best nuances of the Plant vocal chords using all his middle eastern phrasing, other worldly voices, soft blues accents, gorgeous psychedelic swooshes, and the customized heavy rock roar, plus, as an extra bonus, there is some devilish harmonica playing during the title track.<br /><br />`Brother Ray' was a late addition to the album, giving us a genuine heartfelt tribute to the great Ray Charles, starting out with some great barrelhouse piano before leading into the main body of the song. So don't click your CD off as there is a ten second gap between sections, where the band get into something much more modern.<br /><br />The Mighty Rearranger does not miss a trick. Not only does it have great impact upon first listening, but it also grows on you more and more after each new listening. If you have been put off the solo work from Led Zeppelin's old singer with his previous dabbling with such diverse musical styles as doo-wop, synth pop, and even bass and drums, give `Mighty Rearranger' a try. If you enjoy class you will enjoy this.<br /><br />Mott the Dog.g. His work can be heard all the way through the album, but is at it's most prominent best during second song, and first single off the album, `Shine It All Around' where he achieves a bass sound that can only be described as filthy. He is even allowed enough space for a short solo. <br />Unfortunately, due to all musicians having such tight schedules these days, well the good ones anyway, since the recording of this album there have been two changes to the Strange Sensations line up: Billy Fuller moving on up the rock `n' roll family tree to be replaced by Robert Plant's old cohort Charlie Jones, and Skin Tyson being replaced by Porl Thompson, who had played with Page and Plant on their reunion tour. It's a pretty fair swap in both cases I feel. <br />This must not of course take the focus of attention away from the main man himself, Mr Robert Plant, aka Percy to his friends (a reference to his affection for gardening and Percy Thrower, the man behind the gardening programmes on the British Broadcasting Television network. Led Zeppelin's gardening exploits whilst on the road are nearly as well documented as their music). Robert Plant is now in his sixth decade, and although he can still belt out a rocker with the best of them, he uses the new maturity in his voice, that only comes with the accumulation of years, to full effect. He's not kidding when on `Shine It All Around' he sings \\"These are the best days of my life/Bright, strong and golden', or perhaps more tellingly on `Tin Pan Valley,' showing his new re-found confidence and comfort with the past. \\"I come from Tin Pan Valley, and I'm moving right along/I live in a former glory, so long ago and gone/I'm turning down the talk shows, the humour and the couch /I'm moving onto higher ground, I've found a new way out.\\" <br />Mighty Rearranger brings out all the best nuances of the Plant vocal chords using all his middle eastern phrasing, other worldly voices, soft blues accents, gorgeous psychedelic swooshes, and the customized heavy rock roar, plus, as an extra bonus, there is some devilish harmonica playing during the title track. <br />`Brother Ray' was a late addition to the album, giving us a genuine heartfelt tribute to the great Ray Charles, starting out with some great barrelhouse piano before leading into the main body of the song. So don't click your CD off as there is a ten second gap between sections, where the band get into something much more modern. <br />The Mighty Rearranger does not miss a trick. Not only does it have great impact upon first listening, but it also grows on you more and more after each new listening. If you have been put off the solo work from Led Zeppelin's old singer with his previous dabbling with such diverse musical styles as doo-wop, synth pop, and even bass and drums, give `Mighty Rearranger' a try. If you enjoy class you will enjoy this. <br />Mott the Dog.

I was 17 years old when this album came out  (I'm 52 now) and remember buying this album and loving it. B000EULJLU|5.0|With every album, Tool continues it's metamorphasis from compelling prog-metal band, to a band that really matters. 10,000 Days goes beyond the average song format most bands conform to. It is an album full of pieces that flow together. With the exception of maybe, Vicarious, most of these songs are not meant to fit the regular radio format (although it would be extremely refreshing to hear the local stations push the envelope and play some music that does the same. <br /> <br />Vicarious: Excellent song. I could picture this song being on Aenima or Lateralus... definitely the perfect song to bridge their previous material to the new. <br /> <br />Jambi: Another great song. It has that classic sound you can only describe as \\"Tool\\". Cool wah-wah solo. <br /> <br />Wings for Marie: Haunting... Reminds me a lot of Pink Floyd, but again, it retains that \\"Tool\\" sound. <br /> <br />10,000 Days (Wings for Marie Part 2): Ah, the Pink Floyd influence is strong... but pleasantly so, as this song is obviously vintage Tool. <br /> <br />The Pot: This song could have been a B-Side for Aenima... or maybe even Undertow. It's aggressive, heavy, defiant. <br /> <br />Lipjan Conjuring: I'm not sure who Lipjan is, but this is some creepy filler. I would not recommend waking up to this track in an old, dark house that makes odd, inexplainable sounds... like I did. <br /> <br />Lost Keys (Blame Hoffman): A couple of eerie,detuned, sustaining notes on a guitar open this track, giving way to a pleasant riff accompanied by strange voices. <br /> <br />Rosetta Stoned: Another track whose aggresiveness and defiant tones would have fit in pretty well on Aenima... Kind of reminiscent of Third Eye. <br /> <br />Intension: More tabla... one of those cinematic type songs that starts out slow and beautiful, builds into some sampled, frenetic electonic ambience, and ends as slowly as it was born. <br /> <br />Right in Two: Great song. More table, lots of changes in tempo and intensity. Gets fast and furious towards the end (with some of Danny Careys most awe inspiring fills ever... an eclectic ending, and a peaceful fade. <br /> <br />Viginti Trees: The only real letdown for me. Sounds like a bunch of static... Ever see the film, White Noise? Yeah. But this is pretty much a Tool trademark now, closing albums with something we have to guess pretty hard to figure out what it is. <br /> <br />BOTTOM LINE: This album is not Aenima! It is not Undertow! It is not Laturalus! It is simply the next step in Tool's evolution into a band that creates music that is more than just music. 10,000 Days is a masterpiece, a symphony, and just a kick-ass musical journey. Lets just hope 10,000 days is not how long we have to wait for the follow up. 3 or 4 years to develope their art seems to be a good formula. <br /> <br />

B000EJ9MTW|4.0|I've been excited about the Wolfmother U.S. debut for months now.  When I first popped it in, one of my best friends (and a helluva guitar player) immediately started complaining about how \\"derivitive\\" this band's sound is.  And it's totally true.  My friend loves Interpol, and it's no surprise that the knock on that band is that they are \\"derivitive\\" of bands like Joy Division particularly.  Wolfmother IS derivitive, sometimes painfully so.  But it's derivitive of some of the greatest bands that ever existed.  There's nothing groundbreaking about this release.  The vocalist sounds like an intersting mix of Robert Plant, Ozzy, and Jack White.  The music sounds like a combination of the aforementioned singers' bands - Zeppelin, Sabbath, and the White Stripes (and maybe some Beatles and Deep Purple thrown in).  But if you're into heavy music you can't go wrong mixing the obvious lyrical and musical tributes to rock's founding fathers with the garage rock urgency and wild abandon of the White Stripes.  There are some awesome songs on this disc, notably Dimension, Woman, Pyramid, and Witchcraft.  There are some songs that are just such obvious rip offs that it's impossible to ignore.  White Unicorn is so obviously a Zoso-era Zeppelin copy that it's painful; same goes for the much talked about \\"Apple Tree\\" which is so complete a White Stripes rip off that it even seems to have a lower sound quality than the rest of the album, perhaps to make it sound more like the Stripes early garage rock on Jack's 8 track.  All this having been said, if you enjoy heavy music and want to help usher in a new era of heavy bands in the mainstream, you need to support groups like Wolfmother and The Sword, who are leading this new generation of hard rockers.  Wolfmother, with their videos already all over MTV2 and with the backing of a major label, will be the leaders of this movement, for better or worse.  They are an overhyped band, but this CD has great riffs and some excellent songwriting in places, and because of that it's worth checking out.
B000FFJYCU|5.0|I have high hopes for the quality of this new release, and greatly look forward to seeing Grand Prix again. It was a reserved-seat movie back in 1966, and in those days epic movies took their spectacle seriously. (Grand Prix is spectacular in a different way than Spartacus, which in turn is different from Lawrence, etc.)    Back in 1966, or '56 or '46, when actors drove cars in movies, even race cars, they were invariably back-projected. Seemed fakey then, though now it doesn't bother me. But Grand Prix was maybe the first movie to eschew back projection for actor-driving-car scenes. In GP, the 70mm camera that pans and tilts, is literally bolted on the cars. The scenery flying by is real. The actual actor, e.g., Garner or Ives Montand, is out in the weather driving his race car and driving pretty fast, and you're out there with him, two feet away. What a movie.

B000EULJLU|4.0|I remember seeing a couple of Frank Zappa shows back in the late 70s where Frank would stand in the middle of the stage, his back to the audience, and guide the musicians along with an orchestra conductor's wand because the music was so intricate. It sure wouldn't surprise me to see Maynard James Keenan (vocals) doing the same thing at the Tool live shows.<br /><br />10,000 Days is another disk of Tool's signature, complex rhythms and melodies with Maynard at the helm laying down vocals that range from the spoken word to mimicry to clear, precisely sung rockers.<br /><br />Tool stick to their customary three styles of tunes that can pretty much be summed up as 1) hard progressive rockers, 2) dark progressive Pink Floydesque arrangements (\\"Dark Side of the Tool\\"), and 3) just plain wacky.<br /><br />No matter which style they ultimately choose, you would be hard pressed to be able to whistle or hum a song all the way through without the help of your iPod. Some serious musicianship has gone into all of Tool's CDs (with the exception of course for the tracks that they clearly, deliberately are screwing around on). On 10,000 Days they do not deviate from the originality that have made them a top draw in the US and overseas.<br /><br />The originality is sustainable too. It is a welcome relief from the atrocious homogenization of pop and rock radio. Tool's originally is now expected from them. Signature. But it has not lost the originality edge. 10,000 Days is evidence of that.<br /><br />As for the songs on 10,000 Days:<br /><br />1) Hard Progressive Rockers - tracks 1, 2 & 5<br />2) Dark Progressive Pink Floydesque Arrangements (Dark Side of the Tool) - tracks 3, 4, 7, 8, 9 & 10<br />3) Just Plain Wacky - 6 & 11<br /><br />Danny Carey as always is as perfect as Neil Peart of Rush on drums. Maynard James Keenan could end up with his own separate plaque in the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame (whether he'd accept it is another thing). Adam Jones (guitar) has developed a signature sound with Tool where any attempt at imitation will be immediately called out. And Justin Chancellor has been an absolute gift to the band since around 1995.<br /><br />If you're into rock there are refreshing treats for you here. If you liked Dark Side of the Moon there are refreshing treats for you here. Don't pass on 10,000 Days.iately called out. And Justin Chancellor has been an absolute gift to the band since around 1995.    If you're into rock there are refreshing treats for you here. If you liked Dark Side of the Moon there are refreshing treats for you here. Don't pass on 10,000 Days.
B000ETQRCM|5.0|EVER, PJ have taken us through the near \\"Punk-glam-grunge\\" of post-eighties, depressive angst with \\"Ten\\", explored polyrhythms and funk after touring with the Chili Peppers and changing drummers on \\"Vs.\\", then \\"found their roots\\" with the organic tastes of \\"Vitalogy\\", the first hearkenings to the sounds they would become known for. While underrated, \\"No Code\\" and \\"Yield\\" were GREAT albums, but we (and PJ themselves) were still trying to figure out who PEARL JAM was, so there was some lack of cohesion and possibly alienation of the fan base...BUT their live shows held everyone together. It was not until the mediocre sounds of \\"Binaural\\" and \\"Riot Act\\" did I truly begin to question whether or not this band was going to even be around much longer---or whether anyone was going to care if they weren't.<br /><br />But, songs like \\"Man of the Hour\\", while pensive and certainly not \\"rocking\\", along with the fire of their live shows showed that the light was still on...however, the four years of relative silence has been deafening...<br /><br />Now the band brings us the eponymous \\"Pearl Jam\\", which is as good, if not better, than any albums that came before it. I have listened from start to finish several times through and it just keeps getting better. I don't think I've ever heard the band's live sound captured so well on one of their studio recordings. Stone and Mike are playing better than ever (and Ed is playing some guitar on there as usual), and Jeff and Matt are just infernal as the rhythm section for the machine. In this man's opinion, Jeff Ament is the reason why this band has sounded so fresh from the moment they came out of Andy Wood's death with this new band...Jeff's bass lines are so original, so cool, yet so understated, and he uses so many different intruments: a fretless standup here, an 8 string bass there, a 12-string bass (on earlier records, notably \\"Jeremy\\"), a 4-string electric, a 4-string bowed electric, a 5-string bass. He keeps the songs sounding new yet familiar...<br /><br />But I digress, \\"Pearl Jam\\" is a tour de force of organic energy. I cannot stop listening to it. The realization of a \\"life wasted\\" is a scary thought for these forty somethings, and a lot of my generation feels the same way along with them, which adds to the poignancy of the first songs lyrics. \\"World Wide Suicide\\" is the single, but doesn't quite reach the heights for which it was originally intended, at least in my opinion. The trio of \\"Comatose\\", \\"Severed Hand\\", and \\"Marker in the Sand\\" are just phenomenal. I dare you to listen to the chorus of the latter song and to not sing along...this attack against hypocrisy and high-handedness hits hard. Are you listening, Republicans?<br /><br />Then there is \\"Parachutes\\", a lovely guitar based ballad by Stone that took me a while to \\"get\\". The way Ed initally phrases the verses took some getting used to, but when the song turns the mode to the Dorian towards the end just lifts this song to something ethereal, and the message is just so strong...<br /><br />One of my favorites, \\"Unemployable\\", is a blue-collar story with hook after hook, from the guitar riff at the beginning to the \\"Uh-oh-oh's\\" of the chorus, if it weren't such a sad and home-hitting topic this would be an anthem for a generation...it may still be. Who of us aren't \\"scared alive...near to death\\" at some point in our lives?<br /><br />Then there's the final few longs which are fairly laid back, but poignant topical pieces, with \\"Army Reserve\\" and \\"Inside Job\\" standing tall, with the last song being just an amazingly personal look into Mr. Vedder's soul...<br /><br />And the record fits together quite well, each song has it's own space but still feels part of a bigger whole. This record is what rock and roll is about, showing us that judgments based on age, and time, and what came before mean nothing. Listen, and listen again...and when Pearl Jam comes near you on tour this summer, go see what will be an AMAZING live show from what is probably the most important band in American history. Folks, Pearl Jam is America's Led Zeppelin...ory. Folks, Pearl Jam is America's Led Zeppelin...
