It's not as moving because they don't have the voice needed to make it. This is NOT the case with James...the lyrics couldn't be better and his voice works really well to give you one hell of an experience.... one that you'll want to experience over and over.... This is what music is supposed to be like! <br /> <br />Also, there is the fact that this record is made of different types of songs...lyrically and instrumentally which also makes for a great listen because there is no way you can get bored. There are lighthearted tracks like Wisemen and So long Jimmy which are not as heavy as some of the other tracks on here, but the beats are addictive and just fun! <br />Then there are the heavier more emotional tracks like Cry (amazing!) and No Bravery the closing track that left me blown away the first time I listened to this album. There is a raw emotional feel to the last track that really shows James' talent, and is a fitting note to close out a great album!! <br /> <br />If I had to find one complaint about this album is that it is TOO SHORT! I mean come on! You cant give us this great talent in such a small dose...but hey this is just his debut album and I'm certain he'll be around for years to come...so until then I guess I'll just have to keep hitting that repeat button! <br /> <br />If you're tired of hearing the same artists singing the same thing year after year...give this album a try.... but just a warning...you might become addicted. Great job James!! <br />
0425170349|3.0|I won't discuss the plot; the thousand other reviews cover that in sufficient detail. What doesn't seem to be mentioned to an appropriate extent is the extent to which the book's hamfisted politics undermine its several strengths. <br /> <br />As someone reading from outside of the United States, it's painfully obvious to see that the book was written for those within the USA, by those within the USA. Clancy's knowledge of technical detail on weaponry is superb, except when those weapons are owned by countries outside of the US, his descriptions of Canadian weapons fraught with inaccuracies. His settings are often effective and easy to visualise, but when he ignores the difference in seasons between Australia and Britain, these visualisations are cheapened. Even the British characters, central to the book, say \\"chap\\" and smoke pipes. As an author, Clancy reinforces all of the stereotypes of the ignorant American that those Americans so resent. <br /> <br />The antagonists in the novel, a radical environmentalist group, are a crude negative representation of the political left. The brute-force, gun blazing, America-rules-OK methods of dealing with them leave no questions as to Clancy's political convictions. His subtlety in discussing technology is great; the reader is forced to ask why the same intricacy isn't applied to politics. <br /> <br />For anybody with moral or political insight, Rainbow Six is an often exciting book undermined by Clancy's crude political agenda, making it uncomfortable and embarassing to read. The fact that so few reviewers have highlighted this makes one wonder if the aforementioned resented stereotypes are more accurate than America would like to admit.
B000EULJLU|5.0|There has never been a band like Tool.  The only hard rock band with the talent to pull off something as ambitious as Aenima or Lateralus was the Who in their masterpiece, Quadrophenia.  The Who never attempted anything so ambitious again, but 10,000 Days is Tool's third consecutive masterwork.   <br />  Stravinsky wrote the Rite of Spring in the early 1900's and brought rhythm to the fore in serious music.  The Rite of Spring famously caused a riot at its premiere in Paris, but it successfully dragged the public down a new road paving the way for Prokofieff, Bartok and a wave of modern composers who used rhythm in ways unimagined in the 19th Century. <br />   Tool is the Stravinsky of modern music, and 10,000 days is driven by an onslaught of rhythmical expression as intense as in their prior albums.  It is too soon to say where 10,000 days ranks in comparison to Lateralus and Aenima -- it is probably pointless to rank works of such extraordinary complexity.

B0006M4SO6|3.0|The Way Up is the type of music that is ultimately enjoyable and listenable, but requires a significant amount of effort by the listener to achieve this. It seems like a fair amount of music produced by PMG over the years falls into this catagory and whether that is good or bad is a matter of personal preference. As for me, I'm starting to get weary of the effort.    Although I don't so much agree with Gavin's out-of-hand assessment of the pointlessness of the many key and time changes, I do agree with a sentiment he broaches: Oh, for the good ol' days of ECM. Oh, what I would give to have a work from PMG with the same creative barb of Watercolors that so completely and EFFORTLESSLY captivates the musical imagination. It's been a long time.    Ultimately TWU is good piece of work with an interesting mix of urban urgancy (it starts off sounding like bumper music to some national newscast) progressive rock guitar-type hooks (a la Half Life of Absolution) and general quirkiness (Vu does some very odd things with his trumpet), but I just feel the need to vent the sentiment that previous PMG works of long ago have been so much better.    The result is an almost 70 minute long (it's too bad Watercolors couldn't have been 70 minutes) contiguous composition that requires probably as much effort to enjoy as it did to create - and the payoff is not nearly what other works by PMG have been. I wonder how many listeners there are out there who are UP to this kind of challenge. For now, I still am.    If you are listening Pat, please pick up your oddly tuned Guild Starfire 12-string guitar again and compose something like Icefire just one more time...
